text: Sudan's president, Omar al-Bashir, and his South Sudanese counterpart, Salva Kiir, are set to meet in Juba for talks aimed at resolving the long-standing conflict between the two countries.The announcement, made by the African Union, marks the first face-to-face meeting between the two presidents since South Sudan declared independence from Sudan in 2011.The countries have been embroiled in a long-running dispute over their shared border, with both sides accusing the other of violating the terms of the agreement signed in 2012.The talks will be chaired by AU mediator Thabo Mbeki and facilitated by his East African counterpart, Lazarous Kapambwe.The two countries are expected to discuss the implementation of the agreements they signed in 2012, including the demarcation of their border, the withdrawal of their forces from the disputed border region, and the normalisation of economic and social ties between the two countries.Both leaders have expressed optimism about the prospects of finding a peaceful resolution, with Sudan's foreign minister suggesting that the talks could result in the two sides forging a new relationship.The talks come amid rising tensions between the two countries and a worrying rise in violence in the region.It is hoped that the meeting will help to bring an end to the conflict and create a lasting peace between the two countries.

Thousands of residents in Flagstaff, Arizona have been forced to evacuate their homes as a wildfire blazing in the nearby Coconino National Forest threatens the city.The blaze, which started on Sunday, June 23rd, has rapidly grown to over 7,000 acres, prompting officials to issue evacuation orders and setting up two emergency shelters. Firefighters have been battling the wildfire for the past four days, and are being aided by helicopters, single-engine aircraft, bulldozers, and a large fire retardant tankers.The cause of the wildfire is still under investigation, but officials believe it may have been started by lightning strikes.Flagstaff Mayor Coral Evans issued a statement urging residents to remain vigilant."As the fire continues to move closer to our city, I ask that everyone take this serious and stay alert. We are working hard with the help of our firefighters and emergency personnel to contain the fire and protect our community.”The Arizona Interagency Wildfire Prevention has said that dry and windy conditions will remain in the area for the foreseeable future.

Thousands of people took to the streets of Vienna, Austria on Monday to protest the new right-wing government. The protests were organized by a coalition of left-wing activist groups, including some from neighboring countries. The demonstrators called for the overthrow of the government, and chanted slogans like "All of us together, power to the people!"The new right-wing government, led by Austrian People's Party leader Sebastian Kurz, came to power following the recent snap elections.

A local high school student has been accepted to Stanford University, one of the world's most prestigious universities, and will be heading to California this fall to begin their studies.The student, whose identity is not being released to protect their privacy, received their acceptance letter from Stanford in the mail recently. They will be joining a selective group of individuals, as Stanford only accepts around five percent of applicants each year. The student is from a low-income family and was one of the few accepted with a full scholarship.

Former Haitian dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier's lawyer has revealed that the former strongman has presidential aspirations.The lawyer, Reynold Georges, made the announcement in an interview with local radio station, Radio Kiskeya. According to Georges, Duvalier is willing to do "what is necessary" to have his name included on the ballot for the upcoming presidential election.The news has drawn mixed reactions from the Haitian public. Supporters of Duvalier are hailing the announcement as a sign that the once-feared dictator is ready to lead the country into a new era of prosperity. However, human rights activists have denounced Duvalier's ambitions and accused him of trying to manipulate the election process for his own gain.Duvalier, who ruled Haiti as a dictator from 1971 until 1986, has been under investigation for human rights abuses since he returned from exile in 2011. He has also been accused of widespread corruption and illegal enrichment during his tenure.At the time of writing, Duvalier has not publicly commented on his potential candidacy. It is unclear how his political aspirations will affect the ongoing investigation against him or how they will be received by the international community.

At least 18 people have died and dozens more injured in a powerful earthquake in southwestern China.The 6.5-magnitude earthquake struck near Yibin, Sichuan province at 11:19 p.m. local time on Tuesday night. The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) reported the quake at a depth of just 10 kilometers (6.2 miles).Local officials have reported 18 confirmed deaths and 133 people injured, with further damage expected in some rural areas. State media said that almost 4,000 people have been relocated as of Wednesday afternoon.The earthquake has triggered landslides in many regions, disrupting electricity supply and damaging homes.

An incredible sight has been captured from outer space – an intricate corn maze in the shape of an Oklahoma astronaut. This unique, awe-inspiring image was taken by an astronaut aboard the International Space Station.The Oklahoma astronaut corn maze was cut and designed into the shape of an astronaut in a white space suit with the Oklahoma flag waving from the helmet. It covers an area of about 8 acres on a farm just outside of Yukon, Oklahoma. The maze was designed by farmer Mike Krome to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the Apollo 11 moon landing. In the photograph, the astronaut stands prominently in a brilliant yellow field of corn, flanked by smaller logos of the official Oklahoma Centennial logo and the NASA logo.

Two pilots were killed in a Marine helicopter crash in Arizona on Tuesday. According to the United States Marine Corps, the CH-53E Super Stallion crashed shortly before 4pm local time near Marine Corps Air Station Yuma. The aircraft, which was from Marine Aircraft Group 16, 3rd Marine Aircraft Wing, was conducting a routine training mission.The identities of the two pilots killed in the crash have not yet been released.At this time, the cause of the crash is unknown and is under investigation by the Marine Corps. The FAA and NTSB are also assisting in the investigation.The Marine Corps offered their deepest condolences to the families of the pilots and asked for privacy during this difficult time.

Shailja Patel has become a beacon of truth in a world often dominated by spin and hyperbole. Through her writings, speaking engagements, and work with grassroots movements, Patel has been a powerful voice for social justice, advocating for the rights of marginalized groups in all corners of the world.Patel is an award-winning poet, playwright, and author, whose works range from her play Majaa: The Great Gamble of 1857 to her seminal work, Killogy, which unpacks the complex dynamics of gender, sexuality, race, and class. She is also a formidable activist, working to raise awareness about global issues such as gender violence and racial inequality.An immigrant from Kenya, Patel has a unique perspective, one shaped by the experiences of those around her. Through her works, she strives to tell the stories of those who often go unheard, giving a voice to the marginalized and disregarded.Her passion and commitment to the causes she champions are inspiring and energizing, and her courage in speaking out against injustice knows no bounds. With her uncompromising dedication to social justice and unrelenting spirit, Patel stands as a shining example of the power of speaking truth to power.

Botswana has announced a $70 million credit line for Zimbabwe. The new credit line, which is part of the two countries’ bilateral cooperation agreements, is expected to support Zimbabwe’s economic development and resilience.The announcement was made on Monday at a meeting between the two countries’ ministers of finance. Botswana’s Minister of Finance, Mr Kenneth Matambo, said that the credit line will strengthen relations between the two countries and facilitate Zimbabwe’s economic recovery.The $70 million will be provided as a five-year loan, which will be administered by the Zimbabwean government. It is expected to finance a range of projects, including infrastructure development, agricultural projects, small- and medium-sized enterprises, and health services.The two countries have also signed a memorandum of understanding to facilitate trade and investment between them. Minister Matambo said the memorandum would improve access to markets and promote economic growth and development.This announcement follows similar measures by the two countries to strengthen their economic ties. In 2018, Botswana and Zimbabwe agreed to a free trade area, which is expected to improve economic linkages between them.The move comes as Zimbabwe faces economic hardships due to a combination of factors, including drought, hyperinflation, and a lack of foreign currency reserves. It is hoped that the new credit line, together with the bilateral cooperation between Botswana and Zimbabwe, will help the country recover from its economic crisis.

Turkey has recently come under criticism from secular education advocates for what is seen as an attack on their system of schooling. Secular education activists have voiced their worries that the country’s government is attempting to re-impose religious values on the education system, something that has already been attempted in the past.These concerns have been fanned by a number of recent decisions made by the ruling AKP party. This includes the appointment of government-approved imams to sit on education boards, and an alleged move by the government to establish state-funded Islamic schools in Ankara and Istanbul.The government has denied the allegations, claiming that their aim is not to take away secular education in Turkey, but to find a balance between religious and secular values in the education system. This explanation is not satisfying many critics, who point to the AKP’s track record as evidence that these decisions are part of an ongoing move to move Turkey further away from secularism.It has been argued that the move to introduce religious values into the education system runs counter to Turkey’s long history of secular education. Secular activists have argued that the changes are an attack on their beliefs, and that introducing religion into schools is an attempt to control how the population perceives the world.The debate over the government's alleged attack on secular education has become one of the most divisive issues in Turkey in recent years. It has highlighted the stark divide between those who support a secular education system and those who support a more religious one. For now, it remains unclear what the next steps in the debate will be.

The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has announced its biggest budget ever for the upcoming year, reflecting the continuing increase in violent conflicts across the world.The ICRC, which provides humanitarian assistance in conflict zones, revealed that the budget for 2021 is set at a record-breaking 1.64 billion Swiss francs, a hike of nearly 10 percent on 2020’s budget. It will be used to support those affected by armed conflict, violence, and other crises.President Peter Maurer said that the sharp increase was due to an "explosion of global conflicts and violence". "The context of armed conflicts and violence is worsening and those affected by them need our help more than ever," he said."With the additional investments we are making in 2021, we want to ensure that the ICRC can reach more of the affected people faster and more effectively than ever before," Maurer added.ICRC spokesperson Ian Simpson explained that the budget was aimed at helping those most in need. "We want to move our assistance further to those who are living on the margins of humanitarian aid, including people in remote and often contested areas," he said.The ICRC has been especially active in a number of hot spots across the world, including Syria, Iraq, South Sudan, and Yemen. This year's budget will enable the organisation to extend its operations and support to other regions, while also providing additional help to those already in need.

US officials believe the missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 may have crashed into the Indian Ocean, according to reports on Monday.The Boeing 777 jetliner was carrying 239 passengers and crew when it disappeared on March 8th, 2014, while en route from Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, to Beijing, China. Search and rescue teams have been scouring large sections of the Indian Ocean for weeks in the hopes of locating the plane, however their efforts have proven fruitless. On Monday, US officials briefed Malaysian government officials on a new analysis of the aircraft’s movements that indicated the plane could have crashed into the southern Indian Ocean. At a news conference on Monday evening, Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak said, “Using a type of analysis never before used in an investigation of this sort, they have been able to shed more light on MH370’s flight path.”He went on to add, “It is therefore with deep sadness and regret that I must inform you that according to this new data, Flight MH370 ended in the southern Indian Ocean.”While the news has brought closure for some, families of the missing passengers are still left without answers. There has been no confirmation of what happened on board the flight.

Tigrai athletes have achieved a major success at a national competition, taking home 11 trophies. The competition was held at the capital of Tigrai, Mekelle, bringing together athletes from all over the nation to compete in a variety of events.The athletes of Tigrai managed to secure 11 out of the 20 trophies up for grabs, taking home the top prize in several categories. Among the winners were two runners, who took gold in the 800m and 1500m sprints, while another athlete placed first in the high jump.

On Friday, Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe appointed Taro Kono as his new foreign minister, replacing Fumio Kishida. Kono is a senior member of Abe’s Liberal Democratic Party and is seen as a close ally of the prime minister.Kono is known for his pro-American foreign policy and has strongly advocated for cooperation with the United States in recent years. He is also a proponent of regional free trade agreements and has advocated for a more international role for Japan in Asia.Kono has been a member of the Lower House of the Japanese parliament since 1996. He has held various positions in the Japanese government including serving as the Minister of Internal Affairs and Communications, Minister of Administrative Reform, and Senior Vice-Minister for Foreign Affairs.His appointment as foreign minister has been met with both praise and criticism. Those in favor of the appointment believe that Kono will help to further strengthen the US-Japan relationship, while those against it have raised concerns over his past positions on topics such as military expansion, defense cooperation, and energy security.Kono’s appointment is set to take effect from Friday and he is expected to continue Prime Minister Abe’s policies of promoting regional stability, increasing Japan’s global presence, and strengthening the US-Japan alliance.

British Prime Minister Boris Johnson addressed the Labor Party in London on Wednesday, vowing to fight against their leader Jeremy Corbyn in the upcoming general election.Addressing a room of Labor Party representatives, Johnson said that he was standing up for the United Kingdom, and that he would fight Corbyn’s “backwards and nonsensical” policies. He went on to say that Corbyn was a divisive force in British politics, and that the Labor Party was not fit to be in government.“This country needs a government that will bring us together, not divide us,” Johnson said. “It’s time to stand up to the forces of chaos and negativity. It’s time to get Britain back on its feet.”Johnson encouraged the party to support him in the upcoming election, stating that it was the only way to keep the United Kingdom strong. He claimed that Corbyn’s policies would weaken Britain’s economy and security, and that a Labor-led government would not be in the best interests of the country.The prime minister concluded by saying that he was committed to delivering on his promises to the British people and that he was the leader to do it. He urged Labor Party members to support him in the upcoming election and ensure the success of the United Kingdom.

At least 81 people have been killed in fierce fighting in Somalia's capital, Mogadishu, according to a Somali rights group.The clash broke out on Tuesday between the country’s security forces and militant group Al-Shabaab. It was one of the deadliest battles in the city in recent years.The human rights group said that at least 41 of the dead were civilians. The rest were combatants. Casualties also included seven police officers and five soldiers.The group, Elman Peace and Human Rights, said in a statement that it had received reports of civilian casualties resulting from shelling, sniper fire, and heavy machine gun fire in the surrounding area.The group strongly condemned the fighting and called for an immediate end to the violence. They urged both the government and militant forces to respect the rights of civilians and take measures to prevent further civilian casualties.The country's government has yet to comment on the fighting.

Country music legend Kenny Rogers has died aged 81. A Grammy award-winning singer, songwriter and actor, Rogers had a career that spanned over six decades and sold more than 100 million records.Rogers was born in Houston, Texas in 1938 and started his career in the 1950s as a rockabilly singer. He joined the New Christy Minstrels folk group in 1966 and gained fame with the song “Ruby, Don’t Take Your Love to Town.”He achieved crossover success with his pop/country album The Gambler, whose title song became one of his biggest hits. Rogers continued to top the charts in the late 1970s and 1980s with hits like “The Coward of the County” and “Islands in the Stream”, a duet with Dolly Parton.In addition to his musical career, Rogers was also an actor who starred in the movie versions of The Gambler, playing the titular character, and Six Pack.Rogers is survived by his wife of nine years, Wanda Miller, and five children.

A recent poll of Venezuelans has found that 85 percent oppose the proposed revision of the country’s constitution.The poll, conducted by local research firm Hinterlaces, surveyed 1,200 people in the past month. It found that 85 percent of Venezuelans oppose President Nicolas Maduro's plan to revise the constitution.According to Hinterlaces, the proposal to revise the constitution has been one of the most divisive issues in recent Venezuelan politics.Maduro's proposal for a new draft constitution was announced earlier this year and is backed by his ruling United Socialist Party (PSUV). It has sparked widespread protests around the country in recent months.The poll also revealed that 89 percent of those surveyed think Venezuela is heading in the wrong direction, while 68 percent believe the current economic crisis is the worst in Venezuelan history.In response to the poll's results, opposition lawmakers have criticized Maduro and his PSUV, calling for them to abandon the proposed constitution revision.The poll comes just weeks before the national election, which is scheduled for July 30. It's unclear how the poll results will affect the outcome of the election, though opposition leader Henrique Capriles has already seized the opportunity to criticize Maduro and his proposed constitutional reforms.

Chaos, anger, and confusion reigned over the Democratic Republic of Congo on Sunday as the nation prepared for its much-awaited national polls. With almost 46 million people registered to vote, the situation on the ground has become increasingly tense and chaotic.The voting process officially began at 7am, but due to late delivery of voting materials and other technical issues, many voting centres were unable to open on time. Many voters were forced to wait in long lines at some polling stations in Kinshasa and other major cities in the country. The situation was even worse in rural areas, where many ballot boxes were reportedly damaged and many voting centres failed to open at all.Meanwhile, reports of intimidation, bribery, and violence have surfaced. For example, an armed group of militants reportedly forced several people to vote for their preferred candidate in the remote town of Ituri. The government has also been accused of using excessive force to break up protests in the city of Beni, where several demonstrators were reportedly arrested.Adding to the chaos was the controversy surrounding the use of new voting machines, which led to further delays and confusion. As a result, many voters were forced to stand in line for hours without being able to cast their ballots. The long-awaited national election is widely seen as a crucial step in the DR Congo's path to democracy. However, with these reports of chaos, anger, confusion, and violence, it is yet to be seen if the election will have a successful outcome.

In a bid to boost opportunities for people with special needs in Lebanon, a new startup called Brews of Change is aiming to create a professional platform for them to find work and develop their skills.The platform, which started in October 2020, focuses on creating employment for people with physical, mental, or visual disabilities. It provides a range of job opportunities, as well as workshops and training for potential employees.Brews of Change seeks to create an inclusive workplace, where workers can feel comfortable and safe to express their opinions. The company also provides support and guidance to employers to ensure that special needs workers are treated fairly.Brews of Change co-founder Zeina Nassar said: "We believe that everyone deserves a fair chance in the job market, regardless of any physical or mental limitations they may have. We want to provide a space for special needs individuals to succeed and achieve their professional goals."The initiative has been met with widespread approval in Lebanon, where people with special needs are often undervalued and discriminated against in the job market."It is absolutely essential that more companies create such platforms to give those with special needs a chance to become financially independent and have a meaningful career," said Beirut-based activist Karim Bazzi.Brews of Change is helping to break down barriers and ensure that everyone has access to the same job opportunities. It's an important step for the special needs community in Lebanon, and a shining example of how entrepreneurship can create real, lasting change.

Violence between rebel groups and the military escalated in Sri Lanka on Monday, leaving a trail of death and destruction. At least 18 people were killed and 12 others were injured in the latest episode of violence, which began when rebels attacked a group of soldiers in the eastern district of Trincomalee. In response, troops launched an artillery barrage on rebel positions, triggering a retaliatory attack on an army base.The casualties included 11 soldiers, four rebels and three civilians, according to a spokesman from the security forces. It is unclear if the civilians were caught in crossfire or deliberately targeted.In recent months, the rebel group, known as the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE), has been fighting a decades-long insurgency against the government. The conflict has left more than 70,000 people dead and uprooted more than a million from their homes since 1983.The LTTE, which is seeking an independent Tamil state, was declared a terrorist organization by the United States, the European Union, and India in 2006.Monday's attacks are just the latest in a series of clashes between the military and the rebels, and come days after the LTTE declared a unilateral truce. It is not clear how the government will respond to the latest violence. The latest fighting comes amid growing concerns about the humanitarian situation in the country.

Wes Craven, the iconic horror movie director who directed the legendary "Scream" series and popularized the slasher genre, has filed a lawsuit against his neighbor, comedian Pauly Shore. According to the complaint, filed on July 5th in Los Angeles Superior Court, Craven claims that Shore has created an "intolerable nuisance" on the property, through a series of "loud and offensive" disturbances.The complaint states that Shore has engaged in "unlawful and hazardous conduct," such as lighting fires without proper permits, operating a commercial film and television production studio without adequate safety controls, hosting large parties, and inviting uninvited guests to the property.

Activists in Syria say an explosion near the border with Turkey has killed five people.The explosion happened on Monday in the town of Ras al-Ayn, located in northeastern Syria along the border with Turkey. The area is controlled by Turkish-backed forces, according to a local official.The official said that the explosion was caused by a car bomb and that several people were injured in addition to the five killed. The official added that the target of the bomb was a military vehicle used by the Turkish-backed forces. The identities of those killed in the blast have not been released yet.No group has yet claimed responsibility for the attack, but activists say the explosion was likely the work of the Islamic State (IS). In recent months, IS has targeted Turkish troops and their Syrian allies in several attacks.The incident has been condemned by the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), a US-backed militia that is fighting against IS in the region.

Nigerian troops and Boko Haram fighters have been engaged in a fierce battle at a wedding party in Nigeria, sources report.According to witnesses on the scene, the attack began in the early morning hours, with fighters from Boko Haram targeting a wedding ceremony in a rural area of the country. The militants reportedly arrived in trucks and were heavily armed.As the fighting progressed, Nigerian troops arrived on the scene and began to engage the terrorists in battle. Casualties have been reported on both sides, though exact numbers are not yet known.The attackers are believed to have been targeting the wedding ceremony in an attempt to disrupt local communities and instill fear into the people. It remains unclear why the militants chose to target a wedding party, though Boko Haram has been known to target civilians in the past.The Nigerian military has yet to comment on the battle, though sources close to the situation say they are determined to stop the violence and bring an end to Boko Haram's insurgency.

The world's longest sea bridge connecting Hong Kong, Macau, and the Chinese mainland officially opened on Tuesday. The completion of the 34-mile structure marks the completion of a nine-year project and symbolizes the ever-strengthening ties between the three territories.The bridge, consisting of a pair of cable-stayed suspension bridges, four artificial islands and a tunnel, connects the two Special Administrative Regions to the mainland Chinese city of Zhuhai. The bridge cost approximately $20 billion to construct, making it the most expensive sea crossing ever built.Chinese President Xi Jinping attended the opening ceremony in Zhuhai and declared it a "new victory of our great motherland's reform and opening up." His address was followed by a grand fireworks display which lit up the sky above the city.The bridge is estimated to cut travel times between the three cities from three hours to 30 minutes, and is expected to stimulate economic growth in the Pearl River Delta region.

US politicians have praised the "extraordinary success story" of Rwanda, with its stability, economic growth and progress in development during a visit to the east African country.A bipartisan delegation of representatives from the US House of Representatives, led by Congresswoman Karen Bass, visited Rwanda on the first day of a tour of Africa on Tuesday.In a press conference held in Kigali, Rwanda's capital, Congresswoman Bass said the US was "proud and inspired" to see the progress that Rwanda had made since the 1994 genocide, and credited the government with setting an example of success."Rwanda has made tremendous progress in overcoming great tragedy to become one of the leading examples of post-conflict recovery in Africa," she said. "The people of Rwanda have shown incredible resilience and determination in transforming their country and creating an environment of stability, democracy, and economic growth."The delegation also discussed potential areas of collaboration between the two countries, including peacekeeping operations in the region.The visit is part of a broader congressional effort to strengthen ties between the US and African countries. Congresswoman Bass urged other countries to look to Rwanda as a model of success, saying the nation had set an example of African nations rising from the ashes of tragedy to become leaders of development.

As tensions between Russia and the Ukraine increased in early 2014, the pro-Russian Crimean separatists made a decisive move by delivering the Ukrainian territory of Crimea to Moscow.Leaders in the pro-Russian government, which had taken control of the Crimean peninsula during the unrest, made the controversial decision to hold a referendum that asked the people of Crimea whether they wanted to join the Russian Federation.The vote went overwhelmingly in favor of joining Russia, with over 97% of citizens supporting the proposal. Ukraine and its international allies called the referendum illegal, but the decision to join the Russian Federation stood.In the months that followed, Russia took full control of Crimea, and embarked on an ambitious campaign of economic modernization to make the peninsula a suitable part of the Russian Federation. It has since built an extensive bridge to connect Crimea to the Russian mainland, and opened new business and tourist centers that showcase the region's culture and beauty.The referendum of 2014 changed the political and economic landscape of the Crimean peninsula, delivering it to Moscow and ending its days as an integral part of the Ukrainian state.

As the United States intensifies its focus on the war in Afghanistan, attention is turning to whether current strategies are working and what a new approach might be.The conflict in Afghanistan has been ongoing since 2001, with the United States and NATO coalition forces fighting against the Taliban and other militant groups. Recent years have seen an increase in violence and instability, leading to a situation in which the government struggles to maintain control of even its capital, Kabul.It is against this backdrop that President Joe Biden is now considering a new strategy. Biden has signaled that he is open to the idea of a reduced US military presence in Afghanistan, with a focus on counterterrorism operations as well as diplomatic and economic pressure.Several regional leaders have backed the idea of a reduced US footprint in Afghanistan, including Russian President Vladimir Putin and Iranian Foreign Minister Javad Zarif. Meanwhile, NATO Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg has called for "a peace process without preconditions that brings an end to the conflict and establishes a government able to protect its citizens and deny safe haven to terrorists."However, it remains to be seen what the new strategy will be and how it will be implemented. A number of questions remain, including whether the Taliban will be willing to negotiate and what kind of political settlement might be possible. As the situation in Afghanistan continues to evolve, attention will no doubt intensify further on the strategy that the US and its allies decide to pursue.

Police in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) have made an arrest in connection with the killing of an American woman.The woman, a native of the United States, was found dead in her home in Sharjah, UAE earlier this week. Her identity has yet to be released by local authorities, pending notification of her family.The Sharjah Police have reported that the suspect in the case is a 38-year-old male, also from the United States. Police did not release the name of the suspect, but did say that he is currently being held in their custody.The motive for the killing is still unclear, but police have stated that the investigation is ongoing.It is the second homicide involving an American in the UAE this year. In March, another US citizen was fatally shot in Dubai.The US Embassy in Abu Dhabi has not yet issued an official statement on the killing. It is unclear if they are providing assistance to local authorities in their investigation.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) has reported a significant decrease in violent crime throughout the United States in the first half of 2017.The FBI's annual report, titled the "Uniform Crime Report," showed that overall violent crime declined 0.8% when compared to the same period in 2016. This decrease in crime was largely attributed to drops in robberies and aggravated assaults.Robberies were down 5.2%, and aggravated assaults decreased by 4.3%. However, homicides, which make up a small fraction of overall crime, were up 5.2%.FBI director Christopher Wray said the reduction in crime was "encouraging," but that more work needs to be done to reduce violent crime rates."Violent crime has been decreasing steadily since it peaked in 1991, but there is still more work to be done," Wray said.The annual crime report also showed decreases in property crimes, including burglaries and auto thefts, which were down 5.5% and 0.6%, respectively.However, Wray noted that property crimes are still significantly higher than the figures reported in the 1960s and 1970s. He urged citizens to continue to report any suspicious activity to their local law enforcement agencies.

A female entrepreneur is leading the way in the tech world, paving the way for more women to pursue success in this sector.Marie Smith is a successful tech entrepreneur and founder of the popular software development company, XYZ. After graduating from university, she worked as a software engineer for a few years before starting her own company.Smith's business has gone from strength to strength. She has experienced rapid growth and her products have been widely acclaimed for their innovation and quality.She has spoken about the need for more women in tech, saying “We need more women in tech because the industry is missing out on valuable perspectives. Too often we lack the diversity of opinion that drives innovation and creativity.”Smith has even received awards for her achievements and been included in lists of the top female tech entrepreneurs. She hopes to be an example to inspire others, with an eye to the future, saying, “I believe that women can play an important role in creating a diverse and vibrant tech sector.”Smith's success is proof that with dedication and hard work, anything is possible. The tech world needs more women like her.

European Union member states have reached an agreement with Turkey that will send migrants and refugees from Greece back to the country. Under the deal, migrants arriving in Greece from Turkey after Sunday will be returned to Turkey if they fail to obtain asylum.In exchange, the EU has promised to resettle one Syrian refugee in a member state for each Syrian returned from Greece. The agreement also includes €3 billion to support the roughly 2.2 million Syrians already living in Turkey.In addition, the EU will lift visa restrictions for Turkish nationals as part of the agreement, provided Turkey meets certain criteria. Turkey, however, is asking for an additional €3 billion and to speed up its accession talks with the EU.The deal comes after a recent influx of migrants and refugees to Greece from the Middle East and Africa has overwhelmed the country's resources and strained its capacity to process asylum claims. It also comes at a time when the number of people fleeing from war-torn countries such as Syria is at its highest ever.The agreement has been met with both criticism and approval from EU citizens, though leaders of the 28 EU member states have expressed cautious optimism that it will help reduce the flow of migrants to Europe.

Former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert has been spared jail time after a panel of three judges ruled Tuesday that he would instead face a suspended sentence and a hefty fine.Olmert, who served as prime minister from 2006 to 2009, was sentenced in 2014 to 18 months in jail for bribery, fraud, and obstruction of justice. However, after an appeal, the Jerusalem District Court decided to reduce his sentence to six months of community service and a fine of 500,000 shekels (approximately $146,000).The three judges said they felt that Olmert’s accomplishments while in office, and his "great suffering" since then, including his resignation as prime minister, were "considerable factors" in reaching their decision.The controversial decision has been met with criticism from the Israeli public and some members of the legal establishment. Prosecutor Eli Abarbanel called it a "sad day for the justice system".Olmert is the first Israeli prime minister to be convicted of a crime. Although he was cleared of most of the charges brought against him, the bribery charge was a first in Israel's political history.The former prime minister has vowed to appeal the court's decision, citing innocence and lack of evidence. He is currently involved in a defamation lawsuit against a former state witness.

Washington DC – The US House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan and President Donald Trump’s aides have announced a pledge to pass a tax reform package by the end of the year.The promise was made on Thursday following a meeting between House Speaker Ryan, Trump’s chief economic adviser Gary Cohn and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin."The president and his economic team are helping to develop a unified framework for comprehensive tax reform and simplification which we will introduce to the American people in the weeks ahead," Speaker Ryan said in a joint statement with the White House officials.The statement said that the reform package should cut taxes for businesses and individuals, simplify the tax code, and encourage economic growth. However, the details of the plan have yet to be released.Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that "this is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to make the US tax code simpler and more fair for hard-working American families. We are committed to working together to pass historic tax reform that will create jobs and make America more competitive."Despite Thursday’s announcement, many legislators and analysts remain skeptical that the tax reform package can be finalized by the end of 2017. Still, if successful, the reforms could provide a major boost to the US economy.

On Wednesday, international security measures have been increased in response to the growing threat of terrorist attacks. The latest attack occurred on May 13th in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia where a series of bombs exploded outside three residential compounds. The attack left 35 people dead, with nearly 200 more injured. In response, governments around the world have stepped up security measures to help protect civilians. The United States has increased the number of troops in the Middle East, while Britain has tightened airport and port security, and is requiring all travelers entering or leaving the country to carry a valid form of identification.In addition, the European Union has approved legislation to step up the monitoring of airline passengers and to better coordinate police forces across the continent. Other nations, such as Canada, India, and China, have also increased their security measures, though specific details have not yet been released.Despite these efforts, many are worried that the threat of further terrorist attacks is still very real. According to British Home Secretary David Blunkett, "We must remain vigilant and prepared for any eventuality. We must keep our guard up and make sure that our security measures are effective." The terrorist attacks in Riyadh have highlighted the need for increased international cooperation to combat terrorism and ensure the safety of all citizens. This is a situation that will require the continued efforts of governments around the world in order to protect their citizens from the threat of terrorism.

US-backed forces fighting to defeat Islamic State militants in Syria have admitted to encountering "difficulties" as they battle to regain control of the last remaining areas held by the terror group.The Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), a coalition of Kurdish and Arab troops, has been engaged in an ongoing battle to root out Islamic State, also known as ISIS, from its final Syrian stronghold, located in Deir al-Zor province.However, the SDF has revealed that the battle is tougher than anticipated, due to the ongoing presence of foreign Islamic State fighters who have regrouped in the town of Hajin.Speaking to the Reuters news agency, a field commander for the Kurdish-led SDF forces said: "The situation has recently become difficult in Hajin. The attacks by Daesh (another name for IS) have intensified."This admission comes as British Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt met with SDF officials in Syria, where he voiced his support for the ongoing campaign against Islamic State.Despite the difficulties in Hajin, US-backed forces remain determined to reclaim the area from Islamic State militants. In the last five months, the SDF has managed to gain ground in Hajin and, according to the SDF, has killed more than 1,000 militants since its offensive began.

President Donald Trump has filed a lawsuit to block a congressional subpoena demanding his financial records.The suit was filed Tuesday in U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. It alleges that the House Ways and Means Committee, which issued the subpoena, does not have legal authority to demand financial records from the president. The suit also claims that the subpoena, issued to Trump’s accounting firm Mazars USA, violates Trump’s constitutional protections against unlawful searches and seizures.The suit is the latest in a series of legal disputes between the president and Congress. House Democrats are investigating potential conflicts of interest that may have arisen from Trump’s personal financial records, which are kept in private by his accounting firm.The lawsuit, which names Committee Chair Rep. Richard Neal (D-MA) and the chairman of Mazars USA as defendants, alleges that the subpoena is politically motivated. It also claims that the subpoena exceeds the scope of legislative authority granted to Congress under the Constitution.The case will now proceed to the federal court, where a judge will decide if the subpoena should be enforced. If the court rules in Trump’s favor, the subpoena will be blocked and the records will remain private. If the court rules against Trump, he could be forced to turn over the records to Congress.

A new film released in theaters this week encourages people of African descent to embrace their natural hair, celebrating its beauty and resilience. The film, titled "My Fro, My Pride", follows the journey of a young African-American woman, Angie, as she discovers and celebrates her natural curls and waves.Director Tariro Mavondo believes the film is timely and can help spark a dialogue around the importance of natural hair in African and African-American culture. "My Fro, My Pride" has already inspired natural hair enthusiasts in South Africa, Nigeria, and the United States.The film features interviews with African-American influencers, activists, and celebrities who discuss their personal experiences with their natural hair. Many of them have gone through similar journeys and can relate to the challenges of understanding and caring for natural hair.The film also explores the history of natural hair care, from using natural oils and conditioners to creating protective styles that maintain hair health.With this film, Mavondo hopes to continue to promote the beauty and importance of natural hair in African and African-American culture. "My Fro, My Pride" offers a platform to share stories, spark conversations, and inspire people of African descent to embrace their natural hair.

The United States has appealed to the Taliban to join peace talks, warning of increased violence if they refuse to do so.In a statement released Tuesday, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said the US was ready to join the peace process in order to bring an end to the 19-year conflict in Afghanistan.He said the US wanted a "negotiated settlement, brokered by the United Nations, that ends the war, preserves the gains of the past two decades, and ensures Afghanistan never again serves as a haven for terrorists who threaten the United States."However, Blinken warned that failure to join the peace talks would "mean more violence and suffering" and asked the Taliban to use the opportunity to "begin the hard work of dialogue and negotiations".The US envoy for Afghan reconciliation Zalmay Khalilzad is currently visiting the region and is trying to build a consensus on a negotiated settlement.The statement comes after an increase in violence in the country. Last month, the Taliban had launched a major offensive in the northern Afghan province of Badakhshan, which left over 40 Afghan troops dead.The US and other nations remain committed to ending the conflict, but a negotiated settlement is seen as the only way forward. The Taliban must now decide if they want to join the peace process or face further conflict and suffering.

The upcoming Pennsylvania primaries are expected to have a dramatic impact on the power dynamic in the United States House of Representatives. In recent years, Pennsylvania has seen a shift to a more competitive landscape with Democrats vying to take seats in an historically Republican-dominant district.In the 2018 mid-term elections, seven districts were won by the Democrats, a historic milestone for the party. This has paved the way for Democrats to look to expand their gains in the upcoming elections. With the primaries, Democrats have their sights set on a number of congressional seats, both in the House and Senate.“It is expected that Pennsylvania’s primaries could be a determining factor in the control of the House of Representatives,” said political strategist Sean McCormick. “These elections will determine the political balance of power in the House and will have long-term implications for the future of the nation.”The state’s primaries will be held on April 28th and the results could shape the midterm elections in November. Analysts anticipate that Pennsylvania’s primary elections could be some of the most competitive in the country, setting the tone for the House races in the months to come. This could have a tremendous impact on the House, where Democrats only hold a slim majority. If the trend of Democratic gains continues in Pennsylvania, it could be the tipping point for a full-blown blue wave that could bring the party a stronger majority.While the outcome of the Pennsylvania primaries remains uncertain, one thing is for sure: they will be watched closely by political strategists and analysts around the nation as they could very well determine the future of the House.

Eritrea has arrested two US Embassy staff members in what is being considered a significant diplomatic spat between the two countries.The incident happened on Wednesday morning when two US embassy workers were arrested by Eritrean authorities. Although the exact reasons for the arrests have not yet been confirmed, the move was reportedly ‘in response to a US government action against a senior Eritrean official’.The two individuals have not been named, but it is believed that they were both US citizens. According to the US State Department, it is ‘seeking further information’ about the situation.The incident is just the latest in a string of diplomatic tiffs between Eritrea and the US. In the past, Eritrea has accused the US of supporting the Ethiopian-led invasion of the country in 1998 and 2003. The US has denied the allegations.Eritrea has long been the subject of international criticism, with the United Nations accusing the country of committing human rights violations and arbitrary arrests.

The Afghan government has announced a major shake-up to the private security sector, by moving to abolish the firms that currently provide services in the country.The move, announced this week, has been seen as a major policy shift by the Afghan government, as the country works towards improving its security situation in the wake of increased violence from the Taliban and other militant groups.The Afghan Minister for Security Affairs, Tariq Bazan, said that the private security sector was no longer needed, and that the government wanted to take full control of security operations in the country.He said that the government would be “strengthening the security forces to take full responsibility for providing a safe environment for the Afghan people.”He added that, as part of the move, the government would be “increasing salaries for security personnel to make sure they can work without the need for private security firms.”The Afghan government has come under pressure from the international community in recent months to crack down on private security firms, which have been accused of human rights abuses and corruption.There is no timeline for the process of abolishing the private security firms in Afghanistan, but it is clear that the government is serious about taking control of security operations in the country.

China has arrested a Marxist student leader in the city of Guangzhou for allegedly celebrating the 122nd anniversary of former leader Mao Zedong’s birthday.The leader, identified as Lu Minghua, was detained after reportedly giving a speech that was seen as an act of protest against China’s current Communist Party rule. The event was part of a nationwide student movement that has been gaining steam since the arrest of the student-led Democracy Movement in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square in 1989.According to reports, Lu was taken away from a restaurant in Guangzhou and taken into police custody. He was not allowed to call for legal help and his whereabouts remain unknown.The arrest follows a series of raids on similar gatherings that the Chinese government has cracked down on in recent months.The leader of the pro-Maoist student group, Jiao Guobiao, has condemned the arrest, saying, “This shows the insecurity of China’s ruling party. It only has power to oppress peaceful gatherings.”Despite the risks associated with celebrating Mao’s birthday, many Chinese still revere him for the economic and social reforms he brought to China in the 1950s and 1960s.The Chinese government has a zero-tolerance policy towards activities which it perceives to be a challenge to its authority, and it is unclear whether Lu will be released anytime soon. His arrest has sent shockwaves throughout the Chinese dissident community.

In a recent press conference, President-elect Barack Obama has expressed his position on the ongoing conflict in Gaza and the Middle East in general. He stated that he does not feel it would be proper for him to take a stand on the matter until he takes office in January.Obama said, "I don't want to be sending a signal that in some fashion I am putting my thumb on the scales one way or the other. My views on these matters are going to be formed upon taking office." He emphasized that as president-elect he must remain neutral and "not prejudge what I am going to do."Obama was careful to emphasize that this does not mean he is not concerned with the conflict, and that he still plans to engage in talks with leaders in the region soon after taking office. He said, "I think it is very important for the United States not to be idle on these issues. We are going to have to engage vigorously in order to bring peace and stability to the region."

At least 16 miners were killed and several more were injured in a blast at a coal mine in eastern Ukraine on Friday morning. The explosion occurred deep inside the Zasyadko mine, located near Donetsk in the Donetsk region.Authorities say they believe the cause of the accident was likely methane buildup. The miners were working at a depth of 500-700 metres when the blast occurred.Rescuers and emergency services rushed to the site of the accident in the morning but it took them several hours to reach the group of miners due to the rubble blocking the entrances and exits.

East Timor is only days away from attaining official statehood after almost two decades of struggle and conflict.On May 20th, 2002, the United Nations will officially declare East Timor a sovereign nation and will mark the end of a long and painful 24-year struggle. The tiny nation, bordered by Indonesia on the north and Australian-controlled Timor Sea to the south, will become the world's 191st nation.The East Timorese people have endured suffering at the hands of the Indonesian military and pro-Indonesian militias since 1975. Despite the long-standing struggle, East Timor's citizens remain hopeful as they move forward.In the run-up to East Timor's declaration of independence, the country is attempting to overcome many challenges and rebuild from years of instability and conflict. Chief among the rebuilding efforts is the development of a constitution, which is currently being written. The constitution is the foundation for a democratic government, and will determine the nation's economic and social policies, as well as provide a framework for the government to handle conflicts and disputes.The transition period before East Timor's full independence is expected to be difficult, but the country is determined to develop a stable and successful future. With only 100 days to go until the nation is recognized, all eyes are on East Timor and the journey it is taking towards independence.

Lebanese authorities have named four former security chiefs and a former commander of the presidential guard as suspects in a murder investigation into the 2005 assassination of the country’s former prime minister Rafic Hariri.The public prosecutor’s office named the five men, which include Major General Jamil Sayyed, former director-general of the General Security Directorate, and General Ali Hajj, former head of the Internal Security Forces, on Tuesday.The three others are: former Army Intelligence chief Raymond Azar; former head of Presidential security Mustafa Hamdan and former director-general of Military Intelligence, General Mustafa Bakkar.The prosecutor’s office said they were being treated as suspects in connection with the murder of Hariri in a massive truck bombing on February 14, 2005 in Beirut, which killed 22 people and injured more than 200.“

The United Nations (UN) has declared it is time for an Ebola recovery strategy in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The World Health Organization (WHO) has recorded 3,417 deaths since the current outbreak began in August 2018. The UN is concerned about the escalating violence in the region, which continues to limit access for health responders.The UN has called on the international community to work together to create a comprehensive strategy to end the Ebola outbreak, and support those most in need in the DRC. It is important to not only target the infected, but to help rebuild the lives of those affected.UN Emergency Relief Coordinator Mark Lowcock said, “We cannot allow Ebola to disrupt the lives of so many people living in eastern DRC, and the global efforts to contain the virus must continue. We need to create an effective recovery strategy that emphasizes the importance of health, and supports the livelihoods of those most affected.”The UN has proposed a strategy that seeks to support local healthcare systems, provide psychological and medical care for survivors, and encourage a return to normal life. The UN has also stated it is essential to prioritize the needs of those most vulnerable to violence, and to ensure access to Ebola and other healthcare services are safe. Ultimately, the success of any recovery plan will require increased financial support from the international community. The international response must include continued support to respond to the virus and also to protect and rebuild the lives of those affected.

General Khalifa Haftar, the military commander leading the Libyan National Army, has seized control of three key oil terminals in the country from a powerful militia.The terminals, which are located in the eastern part of Libya, have been held by the Petroleum Facilities Guard (PFG) since 2014. The seizure was accompanied by strikes by LNA forces from both land and air, and reports suggest that the militia has since been withdrawn from the area.The move has been criticized by local authorities, who claim that the country’s oil resources should be in the hands of the United Nations-backed Government of National Accord (GNA). Meanwhile, the LNA has defended the move, claiming it is trying to restore order in the country by re-establishing control of strategic assets and infrastructure.The seizure of the terminals has sparked tensions across the region and raised fears of further destabilisation in Libya. The conflict has already seen sharp divisions emerge between rival factions in the country, with each vying for control of Libya’s resources.The Libyan National Army has said it will continue to push for the “full liberation” of the country and, according to reports, it is currently in the process of taking back control of several other oil terminals.The situation in the country remains uncertain, with the fate of Libya’s vast oil wealth yet to be determined.

In a stunning reversal of recent success, Denmark is not expected to repeat its soccer accomplishments from 2002-2004. During this two-year period, the Danish national team won the 2004 European Championship, becoming the first team to win the tournament in history.However, national team manager, Age Hareide, has announced that repeating the successes of the past would be unrealistic. “We’re not in the same kind of situation that we were in 2002-2004,” he said. “The team is still young, and we don’t have the same kind of leadership that we had back then.”Hareide acknowledged that the team has been able to make the occasional strong showing in tournaments, such as the 2012 European Championship, but believes that repeating the level of success from the early 2000s is impossible. “We are focused on the future, and we want to keep improving,” he said.The Denmark national soccer team is currently preparing for its upcoming friendly matches in June, where it will face Brazil, Hungary, and Ukraine. Hareide remains hopeful that the team will continue to improve and show its potential in the future. “We have a lot of work ahead of us, but I believe that we can achieve great things,” he said.

Barack Obama was sworn in today as the 44th President of the United States. Obama took the oath of office on the steps of the Capitol in Washington, D.C., witnessed by millions around the world who watched on television. The inaugural address was a stirring call to service and civic duty, stressing the importance of finding common ground and of unifying Americans in the face of national challenges. Obama proclaimed: "We have chosen hope over fear, unity of purpose over conflict and discord. On this day, we come to proclaim an end to the petty grievances and false promises, the recriminations and worn-out dogmas that for far too long have strangled our politics. Let it be said by our children's children that when we were tested we refused to let this journey end, that we did not turn back nor did we falter; and with eyes fixed on the horizon and God's grace upon us, we carried forth that great gift of freedom and delivered it safely to future generations." Obama was joined by Vice President Joe Biden, who also took the oath of office. In a day of high emotion, there was also a moment of solemn remembrance for those who have died defending the nation.
In the United States, mass shootings have become all too frequent.

Hundreds of South African opposition supporters gathered outside President Cyril Ramaphosa's official home in Pretoria on Sunday, calling for an end to corruption and poor public services.Demonstrators, including members of the African National Congress (ANC) Youth League, the Economic Freedom Fighters (EFF) and others, carried placards, sang and chanted slogans in a peaceful protest outside Mahlamba Ndlopfu, the presidential residence. The protest comes amid increasing dissatisfaction with the president's record on issues such as corruption, weak public services, job losses, and slow economic growth. There have also been concerns over the government's slow response to the Covid-19 pandemic. Addressing the rally, ANC Youth League Deputy President Reagan Booysen called for President Ramaphosa to make good on his promise to fight corruption and to create jobs. He said the president's election promises had not been met and that people needed to take action. EFF leader Julius Malema said that “we are here to remind the president that we elected him to serve us, and not the other way around. We have to take to the streets to remind him that our concerns must be addressed.”The demonstration comes after months of escalating tensions between the ruling ANC and opposition parties over issues such as corruption and public service delivery. With South Africa's economy in recession, protesters are calling for urgent action to be taken to address the country's economic and political issues. The president's office has yet to comment on the demonstration.

Tokyo, Japan — Former Japanese Foreign Minister Taro Kono is expected to assume leadership of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP).Kono, who served as the Minister for Foreign Affairs from August 2017 to September 2019, is seen as a relatively popular choice for leadership of the LDP. With the current Prime Minister Shinzo Abe stepping down due to health reasons, Kono has emerged as a likely successor.This appointment would make Kono the first former Foreign Minister of Japan to ascend to the post of Prime Minister.Kono, who is a grandson of late Prime Minister and founder of the LDP, Eisaku Sato, has worked to cultivate strong international ties during his past tenure. He was seen as a key mediator between the United States and North Korea in 2017 and was praised for his handling of the dispute between Japan and South Korea over compensation for wartime forced labor.Kono is set to officially announce his candidacy for the party leadership later this week. It is expected that he will be elected as the new Prime Minister at a parliamentary vote.

Retail sales in the United States fell by 0.3% in February, according to a report released by the Commerce Department, suggesting that the economy is not immune to the recent market volatility. This is the second consecutive month of decreased sales, following a 0.1% dip in January.Economists had predicted an increase in retail sales in February, with an expectation of 0.2%. A lack of consumer spending is concerning, especially as consumer spending is a key driver of economic growth.Experts are attributing the weak sales to declines in automobile and auto parts purchases, as well as lower gas prices, which can weigh on overall sales. The report also stated that building materials and garden supplies, electronics and appliance stores, and clothing and accessories also showed declines.Some are concerned that the current sluggishness in retail sales will have a negative effect on future economic growth, with some economists warning that more global economic risks could be on the horizon. Despite a historically low unemployment rate and strong wage gains, February's retail sales numbers highlight the risks that may exist for the US economy going forward.

At least 45 people were killed in a wave of suicide bombings that hit two Pakistani cities on Friday.Local police sources say that at least 20 were killed in Quetta, the capital of Balochistan province, after a suicide bomber detonated a car packed with explosives. At least 25 more were killed in the southwestern city of Chaman in an attack by two bombers on a Shia mosque.Pakistan's Prime Minister Imran Khan condemned the attacks in a statement released Friday night. He called for an immediate investigation to find those responsible and said that the government would take "all measures to ensure the security of our people".More than 50 people were also injured in the attacks and there are fears that the death toll could rise further. The victims include both men and women, along with children who were in the vicinity of the blasts.The Pakistani military has launched a nationwide crackdown in response, arresting more than 500 people in the past 24 hours. Officials said that most of those detained were suspected of having links with militant groups.No group has yet claimed responsibility for the attacks, but security forces fear that the Taliban or a splinter group may have been behind them.It is the deadliest spate of violence to hit Pakistan since September 2013, when a series of bombings killed more than 130 people.

Attorney General William Barr faced a Senate panel Tuesday to answer questions about his handling of the Mueller report, days after House Democrats voted to hold him in contempt of Congress.The hearing was divided between the Republican-led Senate Judiciary Committee and the Democratic-led House Judiciary Committee. Barr, who has faced criticism from Democrats for declining to turn over an unredacted version of special counsel Robert Mueller’s report, was questioned extensively by the House panel.The Attorney General was pressed on a number of issues, including whether he was aware of President Trump’s attempts to interfere in the Mueller probe. He also faced questions about his decision to release an incomplete summary of Mueller’s report that was not shared with the special counsel.Despite the heated exchange, the Attorney General stood firm on his belief that the report he released in April accurately reflects the conclusions of the Mueller probe. He also defended his decision to withhold certain information from the public, citing national security interests.Barr is expected to continue testifying before the Senate panel for the remainder of the day. It remains unclear what, if any, action Congress will take in response to his testimony.

Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is likely on track for an extended term in office, despite his ratings having remained flat for the past few months.Abe's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) continues to dominate the political landscape in Japan, with its latest win in the upper house elections of 2019 solidifying its hold on the government. Abe's LDP won more than two thirds of the total seats in the upper house, a result which many observers say gives it a firm mandate to govern.The LDP has seen its popularity remain relatively stable over the past few months, despite some criticism of Abe for his economic policies and stalled trade deals. However, analysts say that its consistent ratings may be enough to ensure Abe is in power for the foreseeable future.Other parties have not been able to mount a significant challenge to the LDP, with the country's main opposition party, the Democratic Party, having seen its support dwindle in recent years.For his part, Abe has expressed his desire to remain in office for an extended period, saying that he wishes to stay in power in order to complete the long-term reforms he has sought to achieve.It appears that, at least for the moment, Abe is set to stay in office, with the possibility of an extended term on the horizon.

Tropical Storm Arlene has formed in the Caribbean Sea, the National Hurricane Center said Thursday.The storm, located about 640 miles east of Barbados, is expected to move westward through the weekend and could become a hurricane in the next few days.The storm is now a Category 1 hurricane with maximum sustained winds of 75 mph and is moving westward at 17 mph.Tropical Storm Arlene is the first storm of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season.The National Hurricane Center is urging people in the Caribbean to monitor the storm and to prepare for heavy rains, flash flooding and possible mudslides.It is too early to tell how much the storm will affect coastal areas, however, people should follow local advisories for updates.Tropical Storm Arlene is expected to move westward and slowly weaken over the weekend.

An explosion from a suicide bomber in Pakistan has killed three Chinese engineers and injured another seven.The incident took place this morning in the Pakistani city of Quetta, when a bomber drove up to a group of Chinese engineers and detonated a bomb. The attack occurred near the University of Engineering and Technology, with security officials saying that the target was a Chinese convoy.The three engineers were killed on the scene and seven others injured, all of whom were taken to nearby hospitals for medical treatment. Their condition remains unknown.The Pakistani government has condemned the attack, calling it an act of terrorism. The Chinese government also issued a statement, expressing its “utmost condemnation” of the attack and offering its condolences to the families of the victims.No group has yet claimed responsibility for the attack, although a spokesperson for the Pakistani interior ministry believes that it was motivated by the presence of Chinese workers in the country.Chinese President Xi Jinping has urged the Pakistani government to bring the perpetrators to justice and to ensure the safety of Chinese citizens working in Pakistan.

A human rights lawyer has claimed that an independent journalist has been abducted in Georgia.The lawyer, Eka Gigauri, told reporters on Tuesday that the journalist's name was withheld to protect their safety and identity.Gigauri said that the journalist was taken on Monday in the town of Kareli and has not been seen since.The lawyer said that the abduction took place in broad daylight and has been reported to the Georgian Interior Ministry. The Interior Ministry has yet to comment on the situation.Gigauri also noted that the journalist was working on a story related to the construction of a power plant in the region and believes this abduction may be related to their work. Gigauri is calling for a thorough and independent investigation to take place and for the immediate release of the journalist.The case has been gaining attention from international human rights organizations and a statement from Amnesty International condemns the abduction.The abduction of journalists is a rising concern in the country and speaks to a larger climate of impunity and government intimidation of the press.

130 schools in Cameroon have been closed due to fears of attacks from the militant group Boko Haram. The move comes after reports that the group has been actively targeting schools in the region.This latest development highlights the ongoing crisis in Cameroon, where more than 50,000 people have been forced to flee their homes due to the violence. In addition to the closure of the schools, more than 800 people have reportedly been killed by Boko Haram since early 2014.The Cameroonian government has recently responded with a “far-reaching military operation” in an effort to drive Boko Haram out of the country. However, experts believe that the threat of Boko Haram remains high, especially near the Cameroon-Nigeria border.The Human Rights Watch has criticised the government for not doing enough to protect the civilians affected by the conflict. It is hoped that the closure of the schools will help to keep the students and teachers safe, although it is unclear when and if these schools will be allowed to re-open.

A Chinese automaker is set to make its debut in the US market in 2019. The company, Foton Motor Co, has announced plans to enter the competitive US auto market with a lineup of crossover and commercial vehicles. Foton, founded in 1996 and based in Beijing, has grown to become one of the top three commercial vehicle makers in China. It has maintained a presence in more than 70 countries, with current markets in Australia, Europe, and Southeast Asia.Speaking to the press about the decision to launch in the US, a Foton Motor representative said the company is well positioned to compete and deliver an "outstanding value proposition" to American consumers. The company will also offer localized after-sales services, allowing customers to make use of a network of parts, service and other technical support centers across the country.Foton has yet to disclose details of the vehicles that it plans to introduce to the US, but it is expected to leverage its experience in the commercial vehicle segment to offer a variety of attractive options for American customers.US automotive analysts have welcomed the news, noting that Foton's entry into the market could shake up the status quo, and bring fresh competition in an otherwise stagnant market.

Greece's Foreign Minister Nikos Dendias has stated that the recent court ruling in Greece not to extradite the eight Turkish soldiers who were accused of involvement in a failed coup in 2016 must be respected.The eight soldiers had requested asylum in Greece soon after the coup attempt failed in Turkey. Their request was initially refused by Greece, but last month Greece's Supreme Court ordered that the extradition order be overturned. The decision triggered a diplomatic row between Turkey and Greece.“The most important thing is that, as a European country, Greece respects court decisions and that is something we must all honor and abide by,” Dendias said during a news conference on Wednesday.Turkey has since accused Greece of harboring coup plotters and has demanded the extradition of the soldiers, a request that Greece has repeatedly refused.“Greece, as a state based on the rule of law, abides by its judicial decisions,” said Dendias. “This does not mean that the matter of the Turkish soldiers who have applied for asylum in our country is closed. It is a case that we must closely follow in the coming days.”The Greek government has maintained that it is a signatory to international law and must respect the decision of the court.

A recent survey of more than 3,000 U.S. high school students has revealed a declining confidence in America's future.The survey, conducted by the Public Religion Research Institute (PRRI), revealed that only 44% of respondents held a "very positive" view of America's future, a significant decline from the 65% reported in 2018. This decrease was mirrored among students of different political orientations, with Democrats dropping from 72% to 42% and Republicans declining from 77% to 54%.Among those with the most pessimistic outlook on America's future were Hispanic and Asian students, with only 37% of the former and 40% of the latter expressing a "very positive" attitude. However, the survey also revealed that there were significant age-based divides, with younger students - those between the ages of 14 and 17 - being far more optimistic than their 18- and 19-year-old peers.The findings of the PRRI survey reflect the overall decline in confidence in American institutions among the population as a whole. According to an earlier survey from the Pew Research Center, only 39% of respondents expressed a “great deal” or “quite a lot” of confidence in the nation’s political system.These trends indicate a pervasive sense of unease among Americans of all ages and political leanings, suggesting that the nation must work hard to rebuild confidence in its future if it wants to remain competitive in an increasingly globalized world.

At least 10 people were killed and 20 were injured in a car bomb blast in the Syrian city of Raqqa on Sunday.The blast occurred in the north-eastern neighbourhood of Mashlab, where fighters from the so-called Islamic State (IS) were operating before they were driven out by US-backed forces in October 2017.Rescue and security personnel arrived at the scene of the bombing soon after it happened and took the injured to nearby medical facilities.It is not yet known who was behind the bombing, but Syrian state media said the attack was likely carried out by "terrorists".Residents of Raqqa say that the security situation in the city has deteriorated in recent months, with incidents of violence on the rise and a lack of public safety.This is the first major attack in Raqqa since the fall of IS and comes at a time when the US and other Western countries are trying to rebuild the city and bring stability to the region.

Dozens of "Occupy Boston" protesters were arrested Saturday night following a chaotic clash between police and demonstrators.The incident occurred as the protesters attempted to occupy Dewey Square Park, located in the city's Financial District. Police officers had been stationed near the park for some time, and when the protesters arrived they were met with a barricade of officers blocking their entrance.Despite multiple warnings from the police to disperse, the protesters remained and began to throw rocks and other objects at officers. The situation quickly escalated, with the police eventually deciding to make arrests. In total, 41 protesters were taken into custody, including 18 who were charged with disorderly conduct and resisting arrest.The events that unfolded on Saturday night have drawn the ire of civil rights groups, who are calling the police action an overreaction to a peaceful protest. Others have criticized the police for using unnecessary force in a situation that did not pose a direct threat to public safety.The Occupy Boston movement is a loose collection of protesters who have been camped out in Dewey Square Park since September. The group's stated goal is to raise awareness of economic inequality in the United States.

At least 21 people were killed in a suspected US drone strike in northwest Pakistan on Thursday. The strike reportedly hit a compound in the North Waziristan region near the border with Afghanistan.Local security officials and eyewitnesses said the attack targeted a compound belonging to a local Taliban commander, where a jirga—an assembly of tribal elders—was reportedly taking place. No one has claimed responsibility for the strike, but the US military has conducted similar strikes in the past. A military source told Reuters that "US drones were engaged in anti-terrorism operations in the region and if confirmed, it will be an attack by a US drone".The strike comes days after a suicide attack in the northwestern city of Mardan killed four people.
