This will be the second vacancy on the court President Trump has had the chance to fill, following the retirement of Justice Antonin Scalia in 2016. Justice Kennedy's retirement is effective July 31, 2018.

Afghanistan’s Chief Executive Abdullah Abdullah has declared that President Hamid Karzai’s re-election does not have legitimacy.The announcement, which came on Wednesday, was prompted by a dispute between the two men over the makeup of the country’s election commission. Abdullah had been critical of the process leading up to Karzai’s re-election, claiming that it was marred by fraud.Abdullah also alleged that Karzai had refused to implement the agreed-upon changes to the commission, saying that the president's efforts to bypass these reforms was an attempt to manipulate the outcome of the vote.The comments come amidst a climate of tension between the two men, and the wider nation. Karzai is due to be sworn in for a second five-year term on August 2, but it is unclear how the latest development will affect this.The dispute over Karzai’s re-election has highlighted the deep divisions in the country, and Abdullah’s comments will likely only increase these tensions.Though Abdullah has announced his belief that the re-election lacks legitimacy, it remains to be seen how this will be reflected in the upcoming swearing in ceremony. With the future of Afghanistan’s governance unclear, it is uncertain how this latest political disagreement will affect the nation in the coming weeks and months.

The United Nations has called for free and fair elections in Lebanon as the country approaches a crucial juncture in its history.The Special Coordinator of the United Nations for Lebanon, Jan Kubis, said in a statement: “In this critical moment, the voice of the people should be heard and respected through free and fair elections, conducted in a peaceful atmosphere and held in accordance with the Lebanese Constitution and electoral law.”The upcoming election is scheduled for May 6th and is the first since 2009. The country has been rocked by political turmoil for over a decade, and the economic crisis has only added to the challenges.Kubis also urged the authorities to ensure that all eligible voters can participate without fear or intimidation, and that the elections are conducted in a transparent manner.The United Nations is ready to provide technical support, as requested by the government, to help improve the electoral process.The election results will be key in determining the direction Lebanon will take in the coming years. It is a crucial moment for the people of Lebanon, and the United Nations is committed to working with the government to ensure that free and fair elections take place.

The United States and Turkey have agreed to deepen their collaboration in the fight against the Islamic State (IS), seeking to further hamper the extremist group's capabilities in the region.US Secretary of State John Kerry and Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu announced the new collaboration during a joint press conference in Ankara on Thursday. The two ministers pledged to work together to enhance intelligence sharing, reinforce joint military efforts against IS, and provide humanitarian aid to those affected by the conflict in the region.Kerry said the US would also provide Turkey with additional assistance and equipment to facilitate their efforts against the extremist group. He also spoke of the importance of countering the narrative of IS and other extremist groups, emphasizing the need for the US and its allies to communicate the values of democracy and inclusion.Meanwhile, Cavusoglu welcomed the US's continued commitment to the fight against IS, stressing the need to better coordinate military operations against the group and to strengthen cooperation between the US and its allies. He also called for more international aid for the refugees and internally displaced persons affected by the conflict in the region.In light of the announcement, the US and Turkey have vowed to redouble their efforts in combating IS and restoring stability to the region.

Dubai, a global leader in business, tourism and entertainment, has been hit hard by the global economic crisis. With many industries taking a major hit, there has been a large decrease in economic activity throughout the region.The effects of the crisis are being felt in a variety of sectors, including real estate, retail, hospitality, tourism and trade. With businesses across the world scaling back, there has been a massive drop in demand for the goods and services produced in Dubai. Many workers have been laid off and companies are closing their doors in an attempt to stay afloat.The government has taken steps to reduce the impact of the crisis on the local economy. There have been initiatives to provide loans to businesses, cut taxes and increase investment into certain sectors. These measures have provided some relief, but the economic outlook remains uncertain.The crisis has also had a significant impact on the people of Dubai. Many have lost their jobs, and others have been unable to find new ones. There have been numerous reports of people struggling to make ends meet, as prices for goods and services continue to rise.The future of Dubai’s economy remains uncertain, but it’s clear that the global economic crisis has had a major effect on the city. For many, there is hope that the worst is behind them, and that the economy will soon begin to recover.

Liberian Senator John Taylor is making a public call for the people of Liberia to judge him by his character and accomplishments in office, rather than by his personal beliefs and activities.At a recent press conference, Taylor said, “As a public servant, I strive to serve the people of Liberia and deliver on my promises. I want the public to assess my performance based on my record and the value I bring to the table.”The Senator discussed some of his most notable initiatives in the Senate, including his leadership on a proposed financial aid package for families with disabled children, a new medical facility near the capital, and a bill to guarantee access to education for underserved communities.Taylor also spoke out against the factionalism and political posturing that has characterized Liberian politics in recent years. He declared, “I strongly believe that elected officials should prioritize the best interests of the people of Liberia. I understand that the political arena is a testing ground for ideas and ideologies, but I also believe that the people of Liberia deserve more than just rhetoric. They deserve meaningful action and tangible results.”Taylor said he is confident that, in time, the public will come to understand his dedication to the public good and his commitment to doing the right thing for the people of Liberia.

A man carrying a suspicious device threatened to detonate a bomb at the US Embassy in Berlin on Tuesday morning.The suspect, a 21-year-old male, reportedly arrived at the embassy located in the Tiergarten neighborhood around 11 a.m. local time. He was stopped by security and was questioned before being taken into custody by police.The man was carrying what appeared to be a bomb-like device when he was stopped, but police later determined that the device was not dangerous.The motive behind the man's threat remains unknown.

A Thai woman who was trafficked to Australia for sex work has won a landmark legal victory, with a compensation package awarded to her by the Australian Federal Court.The court ordered the brothel operator who was responsible for her exploitation to pay the woman $260,000 in damages, with the judge ruling that the woman had suffered "substantial and sustained psychological harm".The woman, who is in her 30s, arrived in Australia in 2015 on a student visa, but was coerced into working in the sex industry by her traffickers. She was held in a small room at the brothel and forced to serve up to 10 clients a night, with no money of her own.In his ruling, Justice Robert Bromwich said the woman had suffered considerable harm, including extreme humiliation, distress and a damaged sense of self-worth.The case is being hailed as a victory for victims of sex trafficking in Australia, with the woman's lawyer, Lisa Flynn, describing it as a “step in the right direction for women who have been exploited in this way.”

The United States has suspended all economic sanctions on Burma, in what is a major step towards improving diplomatic relations between the two countries. The move by the US comes after President Thein Sein, Burma's former military ruler, committed himself to a programme of political and economic reforms. President Sein has taken a number of steps towards achieving democracy and implementing wider economic and social reforms, including allowing the opposition to participate in politics and ordering the release of hundreds of political prisoners.In a statement, US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton praised the Burmese government’s efforts, saying: "This important shift in our policy recognizes the dramatic process underway in Burma today and sends a strong signal of our support." The sanctions relief will have major economic ramifications for the Burmese economy, allowing US companies to invest in the country, lifting banking and financial restrictions and enabling the government to access much needed foreign aid.For Burma, the impact of this move will be far-reaching. By ending sanctions, the US has signalled its support for President Sein's reform process and set the stage for a new era of co-operation between the two countries. It is hoped that this will be the start of a new era of economic and political growth in Burma.

President Trump has called for the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) to review the practicality of companies filing quarterly corporate reports.The President tweeted that having companies report their earnings every three months was "oppressive" and burdensome. He added that having companies report their earnings on an annual basis "may be more appropriate", suggesting the SEC review the requirements.The SEC has not yet responded to the President's request.It is not uncommon for the SEC to review corporate reporting requirements, however the timing of Trump's call is notable as it follows a decline in the U.S. stock markets and tensions with China.The idea of reforming corporate reporting requirements has also been suggested by business leaders, such as JPMorgan Chase & Co.

The World Health Organization (WHO) has announced that Bhutan and the Maldives have become the first countries in their region to eliminate measles. This success means that both countries have interrupted transmission of the disease for three consecutive years, based on data from 2019.Measles, a highly contagious virus, is a major cause of death among young children and causes nearly 10 million cases globally each year. In 2018, the WHO declared that all nations should strive to eliminate measles by 2020, and a number of countries have made significant progress towards this goal.Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO’s Director-General, praised the achievement and offered his congratulations: “I congratulate Bhutan and the Maldives on this remarkable public health achievement that will benefit everyone. This is a result of a strong routine immunization program, good surveillance, and a true commitment to ensure that no one is left behind.”According to the WHO, other countries in the region are making great strides, with the likelihood that more countries in the region will be declared measles-free in the near future.

Singapore is planning a record stimulus package as the coronavirus pandemic continues to batter its economy, with the latest estimates showing the city-state's gross domestic product (GDP) growth turning negative.The city-state's government unveiled plans on Tuesday to spend an additional $6.4 billion in the 2020 financial year, bringing the total to a record high of $74.7 billion. This is expected to include measures to assist businesses and households affected by the economic fallout.Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong said the government would be using fiscal support to "ride out the crisis and return our economy to pre-COVID levels as quickly as possible".The latest Singaporean GDP figures for the April-June quarter show the economy shrank by a record 13.2% year-on-year, much worse than expected. The economy had already declined 0.3% in the previous quarter, its first recession since 2009.The government has imposed strict circuit breaker measures since April to contain the spread of the virus, which have seen hundreds of thousands of people lose their jobs.However, the government has since eased these restrictions and is now looking to the second round of stimulus measures as a way to "lay the foundation" for economic recovery.This includes measures to support the tourism sector, which was badly hit by the pandemic, and additional support for households.With the new stimulus package, Singapore's total spending is estimated to be 21.5% of GDP, the highest ever recorded, surpassing the previous record of 19.7% in 2009.Despite the bleak outlook, the government is still expecting the economy to return to positive growth in 2021, although this will depend on the virus being contained.

A Nigerian family has come forward to confirm that a voice recording circulating on social media is of their daughter, the last remaining Dapchi schoolgirl yet to be freed from Boko Haram militants.Leah Sharibu, 14, was among the 110 girls abducted from the town of Dapchi in Nigeria in February this year. While the majority of the girls were released in a prisoner swap days later, Leah was held back by the militants due to her refusal to convert to Islam.The Sharibu family received the recording of Leah’s voice from a source with ties to the Islamist group. In it, Leah can be heard pleading for her freedom and for the government to accept the demands of the militants. She states that she’s being held “in captivity for refusing to denounce Christ” and that if the government wants her to return home, “they should meet the request of the group”.The recording has sparked outrage in the community, with activists and the government strongly condemning the militants for not releasing Leah with the rest of the schoolgirls. Human Rights Watch has called for Leah’s immediate release, expressing deep concern for her wellbeing.It is not yet known what the militants are demanding in exchange for her freedom. However, the Nigerian government has promised to keep working for her release, vowing to never give in to the demands of the militants.

Thailand’s rapidly aging population is taking a toll on indebted households, creating challenges for families that lack resources to support their elderly members. According to recent reports, an estimated 6.5 million of the country’s 69 million people are over 65, while projections estimate the elderly population could reach 14 million in the next two decades.The growing elderly population is creating difficulties in an environment that offers limited assistance for the elderly. Government welfare programs and pension programs exist, but are not widely utilized due to a lack of financial literacy and issues with accessibility. This has forced many elderly Thais to rely on family members for support, with some households resorting to taking out loans to pay for medical expenses and basic living costs.At the same time, declining birth rates in Thailand are contributing to the issue. Low fertility rates have resulted in fewer economically active people, resulting in reduced social security revenue. This has further limited the government’s ability to provide financial assistance and benefits to elderly citizens.For households already burdened with debt, the trend has been hard to cope with. The lack of government assistance and long-term economic planning has been a major cause for concern, with experts warning that the situation could worsen in the coming years if concrete steps are not taken.The growing elderly population has emerged as a major policy issue for the Thai government. To tackle the challenge, Thai authorities are exploring ways to strengthen the social safety net and develop better public and private pension systems. Officials are also urging families to start saving and planning for retirement as early as possible, in order to be better prepared for the future.

Kenya has made history, becoming the first country in Africa to pioneer a new way of transferring money. The revolutionary system, M-Pesa, was launched in 2007 and is an example of the groundbreaking and innovative technology that is transforming how Africans communicate, access banking services and conduct business.M-Pesa stands for Mobile Payment Service and is a mobile money transfer platform that allows users to send and receive money using their mobile phones. This new system has enabled millions of Kenyans to securely and conveniently transfer money, even in areas where traditional banking systems were unavailable.The success of M-Pesa has been credited with providing financial access to millions of low-income people in Kenya and is having a huge impact on economic development in the country. The World Bank has lauded the platform as a model for other developing countries to follow.The global attention has prompted other African nations to follow in Kenya's footsteps in order to reach greater financial inclusion for their citizens. The success of M-Pesa has propelled the African financial sector into a new age of digital innovation that is changing the way we view banking and finance.It is clear that Kenya's new system for transferring money is creating a ripple effect across the continent and is set to revolutionize the way we bank in Africa. This revolutionary technology is unlocking the economic potential of the continent and providing access to millions of people who otherwise would have been excluded from financial services.

The tension between the US and China is palpable as Manila leader, Rodrigo Duterte, is set to reveal his stance on the South China Sea. Duterte, who recently reached his first anniversary as president, has so far indicated a willingness to pursue an amicable solution to the dispute with the Chinese in the region.Washington has expressed concern in the past that the Filipino leader might move to soften the Philippines' stance against Beijing's claims, which have been heavily criticized by the international community. After taking office, Duterte has taken a number of steps to improve relations with China, including a state visit in October 2016.The South China Sea is a contentious issue in the region due to the overlapping territorial claims of China, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, and Brunei. The situation has escalated in recent years, with the US reinforcing its stance against Beijing by sending warships to patrol the disputed waters.Duterte has taken a more conciliatory stance compared to his predecessor, Benigno Aquino. Aquino initiated an international arbitration case against China, which the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague ruled in favor of the Philippines in July 2016.The Filipino leader's speech, which is expected to take place this month, could set the tone for the next several years of diplomatic relations between the US and China. Both Washington and Beijing are expecting to hear Duterte's views on the South China Sea situation and hoping that it will result in a constructive outcome.

Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad has condemned former United States President George W. Bush and former British Prime Minister Tony Blair as "war criminals", claiming they had no legal basis to wage war in Iraq in 2003.Speaking at a two-day leadership forum in Kuala Lumpur, Mohamad argued that the war in Iraq was a “crime of aggression” and an “immoral war,” claiming that the action caused the deaths of millions of people without achieving its primary objectives.“The leader of the aggressors should be punished as war criminals,” Mohamad said. “But in this case, the war criminals are still walking around without punishment. This is not justice.”

The United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) has pleaded for additional funding in order to continue to provide vital aid to Palestinian refugees across the Middle East.UNRWA Commissioner-General Pierre Krähenbühl spoke on Tuesday to the UN General Assembly and called for a total of $1.2 billion to cover the agency’s 2019-2020 budget.The agency has warned that an acute lack of funding could result in a substantial reduction of its services, including education and healthcare for the 5.4 million refugees registered with UNRWA. Krähenbühl described the current status of UNRWA as “a dangerous uncertainty”, and spoke of how the agency has been forced to cut its budget by $300 million, affecting services for an unprecedented amount of people.The Commissioner-General also addressed the “erosion” of the Palestinian refugees’ “hope for a better future” and said that without further aid, the refugee population would be at risk of “more fear, more desperation, and more instability.”Krähenbühl concluded his speech by saying that the “stability of the region and the safety of the Palestinian refugees and the region as a whole are inextricably linked” and emphasised the importance of providing the necessary funds to protect these lives. UNRWA has since received additional donations from countries including the UK, Norway, the United Arab Emirates, and the United States, which will allow the agency to provide additional services in the short-term. However, to ensure the safety and security of the 5.4 million Palestinian refugees, UNRWA is seeking to find a sustainable and long-term solution to their ongoing financial crisis.

Analysts have said that hopes of establishing a more democratic future for the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) could largely rely on Thailand.The political and human rights situation in the region has been increasingly unstable in recent years, as different countries have seen a variety of challenges, such as the overthrow of the democratically-elected government in Myanmar in February, the unrest in Hong Kong, and the tightening of social controls in Laos and Cambodia.Speaking to Reuters, Southeast Asian politics expert Oh Ei Sun, from the Pacific Research Center in Singapore, said that the way Thailand responds to these issues would be key in determining the democratic future of ASEAN.“For the time being, Thailand is probably the most democratic and most stable country in ASEAN. It can be viewed as a model in some aspects,” said Oh.He added that despite the current political divisions in the country, which have recently resulted in violent clashes between opposing sides, Thailand is still seen as an island of democracy in a region that is increasingly becoming more autocratic.“Thailand should show the way for ASEAN to move forward in terms of developing democracy and respecting fundamental human rights,” he said.Experts have called on Thailand to lead by example in terms of how it responds to the issues in the region, saying it should use its influence to work for peaceful solutions and promote stability and democratic principles.However, the domestic political situation in Thailand could prove to be a roadblock in efforts to create a more democratic future for ASEAN.“If there are sharp political divisions in Thailand, its credibility as a regional leader will be affected,” said Oh.

Chad's announcement that it is withdrawing its troops from the Central African Republic (CAR) has raised security fears across the region. This decision follows a dispute between President Idriss Deby and the CAR president, Faustin-Archange Touadera.The 2,000 Chadian soldiers have been helping to quell a rebel uprising in the CAR since December 2019. The presence of Chad's military was critical for strengthening the CAR government's defence against the rebel forces. Without the Chadian troops, the CAR government's control over rebel-held areas is likely to weaken significantly.The risks for the CAR are not just limited to the rebel forces. The CAR is surrounded by several other countries, who have already expressed concerns about the withdrawal. The United Nations has raised fears of regional instability, while France has warned of a "military void" that could allow militants to operate across national borders.The withdrawal has also sparked worry among humanitarian workers in the region. With the security situation deteriorating, aid groups are concerned about the potential for increased violence and the further displacement of vulnerable people.The situation in the CAR is uncertain following Chad's announcement. It remains to be seen how the country will respond to the withdrawal, and how the situation will develop in the coming weeks.

Pakistan has accused the United States of deliberately scuttling attempts to bring peace to Afghanistan. In a statement released on Tuesday, Pakistan's foreign ministry said the US failed to act on its commitments to support the Afghan peace process.The statement condemned what it described as the "arbitrary termination of intra-Afghan peace negotiations," and said the US "abandoned the peace process" when it ended its talks with the Taliban in Doha.The foreign ministry also accused Washington of not fulfilling its obligations, particularly those related to a reduction in violence, the release of prisoners, and the implementation of a ceasefire.The statement noted that Pakistan had consistently supported the Afghan peace process and welcomed all efforts to promote peace, stability, and prosperity in the region. It also called on the US to re-engage with the Taliban and resume efforts to reach a political settlement in Afghanistan.Pakistan's criticism of the US comes amid a recent escalation of violence in Afghanistan. Over the past few weeks, there has been an increase in attacks against Afghan security forces and civilians, as well as a number of targeted killings.

Amnesty International has called on the International Criminal Court (ICC) to launch a full investigation into the atrocities committed during the years-long conflict between the Nigerian government and Boko Haram.The organization has collected evidence of horrific war crimes and other human rights abuses committed by both sides in the conflict, including arbitrary detention, sexual violence, torture, and extrajudicial killings. In a recent statement, Amnesty urged the ICC to open an inquiry into the actions of all perpetrators responsible for these crimes.The conflict between Nigerian security forces and Boko Haram has been ongoing since 2009, with both sides committing abuses and violations of international humanitarian law. In its statement, Amnesty cited a number of incidents in which civilians were deliberately targeted, including a military strike on a village in Borno State in November 2019 that killed at least 86 people.In response to these reports, Nigeria has said that its military has followed international standards in its fight against terrorism, and that human rights considerations are taken into account. However, Amnesty has argued that the true extent of the violations has not yet been fully investigated and that the ICC should take decisive action to bring the perpetrators of the conflict’s atrocities to justice.“The ICC has a responsibility to investigate and prosecute those responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity," said Amnesty International’s secretary general, Kumi Naidoo. “We believe that it is the only way to ensure justice for the victims of this horrendous conflict and to end the cycle of impunity.”The ICC has yet to respond to Amnesty's call, and it remains to be seen whether the court will take up the investigation.

Pakistan has claimed victory over militants in the Swat Valley, as its military announced the successful clearing of the region's capital of militants today.According to the government, security forces have now regained complete control of Mingora, which was seized by Taliban fighters in April. The militant group had threatened to impose strict Islamic law on the entire valley and its estimated 2 million people.The Pakistani military has been carrying out a major offensive against militants since mid-May in the nearby area of Buner. Last week the army said it had taken full control of the region, a claim that was backed up today with the announcement of a successful clearing of Mingora.Army spokesman Major General Athar Abbas said in a press conference today that security forces now had control of the city centre, but that troops were still searching for isolated pockets of militants in the streets.He added that the aim of the offensive had been achieved and that the situation had been completely reversed. The military said that security would now be increased in the region to prevent any further incursions from the Taliban.The army has also been providing aid to those who have fled the area. Abbas said that the military was committed to helping the local population to rebuild their lives.The victory in Mingora marks a significant milestone in Pakistan's war against the Taliban, although military officials warned that further militants remain in the Swat Valley. The success of the offensive is likely to give the country's government a boost in its efforts to combat the militant group.

One of Russia's wealthiest women, Natalia Fileva, has been tragically killed in a plane crash in Germany.The 55-year-old entrepreneur, who was estimated to be worth more than $600 million, was the chairperson of the board of directors at the S7 airline company. The incident occurred on Sunday afternoon, when Fileva was flying from Munich to Sochi in a private jet. The aircraft reportedly went off the radar after 10 minutes of taking off and crashed near Ernsdorf, in the district of Fürth, near Nuremberg. The three other people aboard the plane were also killed in the crash. The German police have stated that the plane plummeted to the ground in a steep angle shortly after takeoff. The cause of the crash is yet to be determined. The news of Fileva's death has been met with sadness in her home country. She was an advocate for the increased participation of women in the business world and was highly respected by her peers and employees. Fileva is survived by her husband, Vladislav Filev, and her daughter, Ekaterina, who were not aboard the plane. The S7 airline company has offered condolences to Fileva's family. This is an incredibly heartbreaking moment for all of us, said Dmitry Mestnikov, head of communications for S7 Airlines. We will never forget the hardworking and generous person that Natalia Fileva was.

Five British men were sentenced to life in prison on Friday for their involvement in a terror plot which aimed to cause destruction at an English army barracks.The five men, Imran Mahmood, Jahangir Alom, Mohammed Chowdhury, Gurukanth Desai and Shah Rahman, had planned to bomb an armory, located at an army barracks in Southern England, in 2012. The plot was foiled by security services, and the five men were arrested and charged with terrorism offenses.The men were found guilty after a trial at Woolwich Crown Court last year, in which security services presented evidence which showed the extent of their involvement in the plot. Prosecutors were able to show how the men had procured weapons, conducted reconnaissance missions, and discussed the potential targets and plans for the attack.In his sentencing statement, the judge, Mr. Justice Sweeney, stated that "the sentences in this case will be life imprisonment and will be served with no opportunity for parole". He went on to explain that the plot was a "very serious offence which involved an extensive amount of planning over a significant period of time".The sentences received by the five men are a stark reminder of the dangers of extremism, and the consequences of engaging in such dangerous activities. In a statement issued shortly after the sentencing, a representative of Counter Terrorism Policing said that the sentences "reflect the seriousness of the offence and the consequences had the attack been successful".

Minorities remain largely under-represented in the European Parliament following the 2019 elections, raising concern among advocates for minority rights.The European Parliament, which is composed of 751 members from 28 countries, saw little increase in the number of minority representation from the 2014 elections. Among the newly elected members, only 4% identify as a person of color, a figure that has remained stagnant in recent years. Moreover, the majority of minority representation comes from the United Kingdom, which accounts for 13% of all elected minority members, leaving the rest of the European Union with a total of less than 1%.The lack of minority representation is particularly striking when compared to the demographics of Europe. Studies show that 13.7% of the population in the European Union identify as a person of color, a figure that clearly isn't represented in the European Parliament.Recent attempts to boost the number of minority representatives in European Union institutions have seen little success. Only seven countries have met or exceeded the European Commission's target for non-white candidates in the elections, which recommends that 20% of candidates from a given country should be of a minority background.The European Commission President, Ursula von der Leyen, has said that she wants the European Union to become a leader in diversity and inclusion, but so far there has been little to show for it. Advocates for minority rights hope that new initiatives and policies, such as a diverse slate of candidates, will be implemented to ensure that minority voices are better represented in the European Parliament and across all European Union institutions.

French rock star Bertrand Cantat has been transferred from his hospital bed to a prison cell today, as he is due to start serving his 8 year sentence for the manslaughter of his long-time partner, Marie Trintignant.The move comes after Cantat was deemed fit to face imprisonment, following the prosecutor’s appeal against a decision to allow him to finish his sentence under house arrest.Cantat, 46, was found guilty of having caused Trintignant’s death in a Paris hotel room in 2003, by hitting her several times in the face. The two had been in a relationship for 11 years, until the fatal altercation.The high-profile case garnered considerable public attention and sparked a debate over the French legal system.The rock star had been receiving medical treatment in a Paris hospital since being sentenced in July this year.

In a rare and welcome sign of progress in the conflict-torn region of north-eastern Nigeria, a militia group has released nearly 900 children who had been under their control since February this year.The release of the children, which was facilitated by the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF), marked the end of a lengthy negotiation process. The 900 children, mostly between the ages of 8 and 18, had been used as fighters, cooks and even human shields by the militia group.Rights groups and the Nigerian government have long accused the militia of involvement in crimes against humanity including the abduction of hundreds of schoolgirls. This recent release is a major sign of goodwill on the part of the militia, and is hoped to lead to an improvement in the security situation in the region.According to UNICEF, the released children are being provided with medical and psychological support, as well as education, vocational training and counselling.“These children have been separated from their families and society for far too long and face significant challenges to rebuild their lives,” said Manuel Fontaine, UNICEF’s Regional Director for West and Central Africa. “Reintegrating children who have been associated with armed forces or armed groups is not easy. It requires coordinated efforts and long-term commitment.”The release of the children is a small but significant step in the right direction for the region and those affected by the conflict. The Nigerian government is now hoping that this will be followed by further negotiations with the militia in order to secure the release of other children still in their custody.

Iraqi officials announced on Tuesday that they had arrested a high-ranking insurgent connected to a string of car bombings that rocked Baghdad in recent weeks.The Iraqi Interior Ministry said that the insurgent had been identified as one of the primary suspects responsible for the car bombings that had taken place in a number of neighborhoods in Baghdad over the last few weeks. The ministry added that the suspect was linked to other high-profile insurgent activities in the area.The insurgent was arrested on Monday in a raid on a location in one of the targeted neighborhoods in Baghdad. The Iraqi Interior Ministry said that a number of other suspects were also taken into custody as part of the operation.No casualties were reported in the raid and no further details have been released. The Iraqi government has not yet released the suspect's name or details about the car bomb plot.The string of car bombings have been one of the major security concerns in Baghdad in recent weeks.

The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must strengthen its oversight of state and local environmental laws, a government watchdog report says.In a report released this week, the Office of the Inspector General said that the EPA needs to improve its monitoring and enforcement of the Clean Water Act in light of the Flint water crisis. The crisis, which began in 2014, saw the city's water supply contaminated with lead, endangering thousands of people.The OIG report noted that while the EPA has since taken steps to improve its state oversight capabilities, they remain insufficient. According to the report, the EPA has failed to hold states and local entities accountable for following Clean Water Act regulations.The OIG said the agency needs to do more to ensure the enforcement of laws like the Clean Water Act. It recommended that the EPA impose more stringent standards on state and local compliance.The report also called for additional resources to improve the EPA’s oversight of state and local environmental laws.The EPA responded to the report by saying it “will continue to strive for the highest possible standards for environmental protection." The agency also said it “will take the recommendations outlined in the OIG report seriously and will move swiftly to make the appropriate changes."The OIG’s findings come at a time when the EPA is under increasing scrutiny following the Flint water crisis. The agency was heavily criticized for its response to the crisis and was accused of failing to take swift action.

A mystery has surrounded the White House over the past few days after an oak tree gifted to President Donald Trump by French President Emmanuel Macron seemingly vanished.The tree, which had become a symbol of friendship between the two world leaders, was planted during Macron's state visit to the White House in April 2018. Macron had traveled to Washington with the sapling from a tree that had grown at the site of the Battle of Belleau Wood in France, where thousands of U.S. Marines died in World War I.The White House has remained tight-lipped about the tree's whereabouts, with some speculating that it might have been removed for safety reasons. Others have speculated that it might have simply died and was removed.Despite the speculation, no official explanation has been offered and the White House has declined to comment further. Until the mystery is solved, Macron's gift to the White House remains a missing piece of the puzzle.

Today marks the 60th anniversary of the founding of the People’s Republic of China, a day celebrated across the nation with parades and festivities to honor the momentous milestone.Since the proclamation of the People's Republic of China on October 1, 1949, the Chinese people have achieved many accomplishments that have improved the livelihood of its citizens and brought it into the global spotlight.Under the leadership of the Communist Party of China, the country has enjoyed rapid economic development that has resulted in reduced poverty, increased wages, and greatly improved infrastructure.Social policies have made education more accessible to all, medical care has improved, and the Chinese economy has become more integrated with the world, allowing more Chinese citizens to reap the rewards of globalization.In addition, China has increasingly become a global political leader, engaging in diplomacy and international trade, and playing a role in global security.This anniversary marks a significant milestone for the country, and people across the country are celebrating the success they have achieved under the Communist rule. The celebration includes military parades, fireworks, concerts, and other festivities.Despite the progress and success of the last 60 years, the country still faces numerous challenges. Officials hope that the spirit of the 60th anniversary will help lead to a more prosperous future for China and its people.

Pope Benedict XVI is a German theologian and the 265th Pope of the Catholic Church. He was elected in April 2005, succeeding John Paul II, and was the first pope to resign since Gregory XII in 1415. Benedict XVI was born in Bavaria, Germany, in 1927. He studied theology and philosophy at the University of Munich and in 1951 joined the Bavarian clergy. He was ordained a priest in 1951 and his rise in the Catholic Church was swift. In 1981, Pope John Paul II appointed him prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, making him one of the most powerful people in the Church.In 2005, at the age of 78, he was elected pope, becoming the oldest person to assume the papacy in 300 years. He was known for taking a traditional stance on issues such as abortion and same-sex marriage, which were highly contested during his tenure. In 2013, after eight years of papacy, he became the first pope in modern times to resign from office.Pope Benedict XVI was praised for his strong spiritual leadership and his commitment to the study of theology. He was a prolific writer, having authored three books and a large number of essays and homilies. His writings focused heavily on the connection between faith and reason. He also took a lead role in developing the Catechism of the Catholic Church, a compilation of the Church's teachings. Since his resignation, Benedict XVI has mostly kept a low profile. He resides in the Vatican and continues to participate in certain events with the Church.

Lithuania is on track to see a shift in power, with the opposition party projected to take the majority of votes in the upcoming parliamentary elections. According to exit polls conducted by independent polling organizations, the opposition party is currently leading with 51.6% of the vote, with the current governing party in second at 39.8%. This would be a significant departure from the current status quo, where the governing party holds a majority in the Lithuanian parliament. The leader of the opposition party, Algirdas Butkevičius, has been quoted as saying that he is optimistic about the results. "We are confident that the Lithuanian people have chosen to go in a different direction than they have in recent years," said Butkevičius.

Girard, a New Jersey native, has made history by winning the WBA Light-Heavyweight Boxing Title on December 23rd. The match against his opponent, Lucio Vittorio Tisci, went the full twelve rounds and ended with a unanimous points victory for Girard.The championship fight began with Girard staying active in the ring, successfully trading punches and dominating the pace. By round five, Girard had established a consistent lead on all three judges’ scorecards. Tisci tried to gain momentum in the later rounds, but his efforts were not enough to overcome Girard’s advantage.At the final bell, all three judges scored the fight 116-112 in favor of Girard, awarding him the WBA Light-Heavyweight Boxing Title. After the match, Girard expressed his joy in finally achieving his dream of becoming a champion.“It’s an incredible feeling to finally be a champion,” said Girard in the post-fight press conference.

Israel has welcomed a call from the Arab League for the resumption of Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.On Saturday, the Arab League announced its support for a US proposal for the talks to be restarted with the backing of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and Bahrain.The call follows a meeting between US President Donald Trump and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Washington DC. Trump said that the meeting was “productive” and Netanyahu said that “the possibilities for peace” were discussed.The talks would be part of a wider effort to seek a peaceful resolution to the decades-long Israeli-Palestinian conflict.Netanyahu has welcomed the Arab League’s statement, saying it is “a positive development for peace”. He also thanked Trump and his team for their efforts to “promote direct negotiations between us and the Palestinians”.The Palestinian Authority, however, is yet to react to the statement.The Arab League’s call for Israeli-Palestinian talks is seen as an important step in bringing the two sides closer to a peaceful resolution. With the help of US-mediated negotiations, it is hoped that the conflict can be resolved and the two sides can establish peaceful relations.

Refugees living in Belgium are voicing their fear of backlash from the government as the number of those fleeing to the country continues to increase. In recent weeks, thousands of asylum seekers have arrived in the small country, placing a strain on public services and sparking a backlash from certain politicians.Refugees, particularly those from Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan, are worried about the rhetoric that is being used in Belgium against them. Many fear a roll back of policies which provide them with a safe place to live and work.“It's very worrying to hear people referring to refugees as a 'threat',” said Faisal, a Syrian refugee living in Brussels. “I don't know what is going to happen next. All I want is a safe and secure place to live and work.”The Belgian government has promised to continue to provide assistance to refugees, but some politicians have called for restrictions and tougher security measures. “We must ensure that our borders are secure and that we know who is coming into our country,” said Minister of Immigration, Theo Francken.The UN High Commissioner for Refugees has criticized this rhetoric and warned that it could lead to a dangerous atmosphere of xenophobia in the country. “Refugees should be seen as victims of conflict and violence, not as a threat to our security or economy,” said Filippo Grandi, UN High Commissioner for Refugees. “They deserve our protection and assistance.” In the face of increased tensions, refugees are still hoping for a safe place in Belgium. “I just want to be able to live my life in peace,” said Faisal.

A new report from the European Union has revealed that both Georgia and Russia were at fault during the 5-day war between the two countries in 2008.The European Union was tasked with identifying the main perpetrators of the conflict which saw the breakaway regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia gain more autonomy from Georgia.The report found that Georgia initiated the conflict by launching an attack against South Ossetia on August 7th 2008 and that the Russian military response was disproportionate and in breach of international law. It concluded that Russia committed a violation of Georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity.The report also criticized Georgia for failing to prevent the outbreak of violence and failing to exercise effective control over its forces.The European Union expressed its hope that the two sides would now implement the ceasefire agreements which had been put in place in 2008. The agreements provide for the deployment of international monitors to ensure peace is kept in the region.The report marks an important step towards establishing the facts and the truth regarding the 2008 war. It is hoped that the findings will help foster better dialogue and mutual understanding between the two countries.

A top US General warned this week that enemies of the United States could misinterpret the ongoing debate around Iraq as a sign of division or weakness. Speaking to reporters, General Joseph Votel expressed concern that if enemies are not convinced of US resolve, they could be emboldened to test US commitment.“I think enemies are monitoring our debate,” said General Votel. “They are looking at what we are saying about Iraq, and they may use that as a measure to judge our commitment to the region and our alliances.”General Votel also emphasized that the debate must not be allowed to overshadow the hard work of US forces in Iraq. “I urge you not to forget the progress that we are making in Iraq,” he said. “The efforts of US forces in the region are making a real difference for the people of Iraq.”This is not the first time US military leaders have expressed concern over potential misinterpretation of the Iraq debate. General John Nicholson, who is retiring this year as the commander of the Afghanistan mission, has previously warned of adversaries viewing US divisions as a sign of weakness.

The Occupy Movement is aiming to have a renewed physical presence with the launch of a series of nationwide protests this week. Taking a cue from past demonstrations, the group is seeking to reignite the energy that sparked the movement three years ago and amplify their voices around a number of issues.Organizers have called for rallies, marches, and teach-ins in over 30 cities across the country on Wednesday, including New York, San Francisco, and Chicago. The demonstrations are said to “move beyond the encampments and squares of 2011” and focus on a wider range of issues, including inequality, climate change, and mass incarceration.Speaking in support of the protests, local community organizer Sayeh Rajaian said, “We must continue to channel the demands of the 99% for economic justice and equality. We must open our eyes to the complexity of our society and acknowledge the tremendous inequality that persists.”“Our voices will be louder this time around and our energy will be more focused," Rajaian continued. "I am calling on everyone to join in this inspiring nationwide movement and to be a part of history.”The protests are expected to be peaceful and organizers are planning to end the week’s activities with a unity rally in New York’s Zuccotti Park, the birthplace of the Occupy Movement.

Congress is currently reviewing the risks of bioterrorism in the wake of recent attacks.The review was prompted by a report from the National Security Council which concluded that the risk of a bioterrorist attack is "substantial" in the United States. The report highlighted certain weaknesses in the nation's public health infrastructure and the lack of preparedness for an attack.A bioterrorist attack is defined as an act of terror involving the intentional release of a pathogen such as bacteria, viruses, or fungi that can cause illness, death, or economic loss. Examples of bioterrorism include the anthrax letters of 2001 and the Tokyo subway sarin attack in 1995.Congressional experts have identified several potential steps for reducing the risk of a bioterrorist attack in the US. These include strengthening the public health infrastructure, developing improved surveillance techniques, and providing federal funding for research into bioterrorism.The risk of bioterrorism is a real concern, but Congress will need to carefully weigh any proposed measures against their potential impact on civil liberties and other areas.In the meantime, the National Security Council has recommended that all government agencies, companies, and private citizens review their existing bioterrorism preparedness plans and implement any necessary changes.

Voters in Malawi turned out in large numbers on Tuesday to elect a new president, lawmakers and local councilors in a fiercely contested poll that is seen as a crucial test of stability for the southern African country.The incumbent president, Peter Mutharika, is seeking a second term in office and faces stiff competition from seven other candidates, including two former presidents. Mutharika has based his campaign on economic progress and is counting on his record of delivering jobs, new infrastructure projects and economic growth to bolster his chances.The election is also likely to be a close race for the 193 parliamentary seats and 462 local councilor positions being contested. Political experts have predicted that the outcome of the election could be determined by a slender margin.Malawians are hopeful that this election will bring about much needed change in the country, with expectations for improved rule of law, better healthcare and education, and greater economic opportunity.The results of the election will be released in the coming weeks and the world will be watching to see who will be Malawi's next leader.

Actor Tim Conway of "The Carol Burnett Show" has passed away at age 85. Conway was best known for his role in the classic TV show, and for his improvisational sketches.Conway was born on December 15, 1933 in Willoughby, Ohio. His career began in the late 1950s when he appeared on the "Steve Allen Show" and then "The Tonight Show". After that, he was a regular on "McHale's Navy" and appeared in several Disney films.But it was his role on the "Carol Burnett Show" that he is most remembered for. He was a regular cast member from 1967 to 1978 and was one of the show's most popular stars. Conway won an Emmy in 1976 for outstanding writing for a variety show and six more Emmys for his performances.Conway is survived by his wife of 35 years, Char Defeo, and their two daughters, Jackie and Kelly. He also leaves behind three children from his previous marriage - Tim Jr., Jaime, and Corey - as well as seven grandchildren.Conway was a beloved figure in the entertainment industry and fans around the world will mourn his passing. He will be remembered for bringing joy to millions of viewers with his sketches and performances. He will be missed.

The Swiss Red Cross hostage Andreas Notter has been released in the Philippines, after being held captive by the Abu Sayyaf militant group for more than a month.Notter, who has been working as a humanitarian aid worker for the Swiss Red Cross since 2012, was captured on January 15 while travelling on a ferry with two other colleagues. He was the only one held hostage, while the other two were released just days after.The Swiss Foreign Ministry confirmed the release on Monday, stating that the Swiss citizen had been “freed from his kidnappers” and is in good health.In a statement, the Swiss government thanked the Philippine authorities “for their continuous efforts and commitment in the past weeks”, adding that it “greatly appreciates the seriousness and dedication with which the Philippine government has dealt with the kidnapping”.Notter is now being treated at a hospital in the southern city of Davao. He is expected to return to his home country soon.The Swiss Red Cross has expressed its immense relief at the news, saying that they are “glad that our colleague Andreas Notter is finally free”. The organization has also called for the release of the remaining hostages held by the Abu Sayyaf.

US President Donald Trump has rejected suggestions of strained relations between the United States and the United Kingdom, after making negative comments about the British Prime Minister Theresa May in an interview.In the interview with the British tabloid newspaper The Sun, Mr. Trump accused Mrs. May of not listening to his advice on Brexit, dismissed her proposed trade deal with the US, and described her approach as “very unfortunate”. He even seemed to endorse Boris Johnson, her former Foreign Secretary, as an ideal successor.At a joint press conference with Mrs. May on Friday, President Trump sought to dismiss any suggestion of a rift. He claimed that his interview with The Sun had been “generally fine”, and described the relationship between the US and UK as “the highest level of special”.Mrs. May also appeared to brush aside the dispute, claiming that “the vast majority of the things we discussed” were not reported in the interview.Meanwhile, President Trump was greeted with anti-Trump protests in London and other parts of Britain, as he began his four-day visit to the United Kingdom on Thursday. Tens of thousands of people have signed up for protests in the capital, with many calling for his impeachment.

Mali's President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita has started a new term in office, but with familiar problems and opponents. The president was reelected in August in a runoff against Soumaila Cisse, although the poll was marred by low turnout, boycotts and accusations of fraud.Keita's new five-year term was inaugurated with a grand ceremony in Bamako, the capital of Mali. The president took the opportunity to declare that his "first priority is to restore peace to the country."A fragile peace was brokered between the Malian government and rebel Tuareg forces in 2015, but violence has continued to flare up in the north. Keita's administration has also been beset by accusations of corruption and a crackdown on dissidents and opposition leaders.Cisse has rejected the official results of the election and called for a recount. He has also initiated legal action at the country's highest court of appeals, alleging that the vote was manipulated and that Keita has "institutionalised fraud."The 77-year-old president is a veteran politician who previously served as prime minister from 1994 to 2000. Keita has vowed to "restore the authority of the state" but his opponents are concerned that his heavy-handed tactics will further alienate the population.With a new term comes new opportunities for Mali, but it's still uncertain if Keita can resolve the ongoing disputes and get the country back on its feet.

The South African Parliament is expected to debate the possibility of impeaching President Jacob Zuma later today. The discussion, which will begin at 1 PM South African Standard Time, comes after several accusations of corruption against President Zuma and the South African government.Opposition leaders in the Parliament have strongly urged for the impeachment of Zuma due to mounting allegations of misuse of state funds and other unethical practices. While the debate over Zuma's impeachment may last several days, the potential repercussions of a successful impeachment could have far-reaching effects across the entire continent.President Zuma, who has been in office since 2009, has denied the allegations against him and pledged to provide “all necessary documentation” to support his defence. Although Zuma has the backing of the ruling African National Congress, his detractors are hoping to bring about a much-needed change in South African leadership. The outcome of the impeachment debate will set a powerful precedent in the country and will be closely watched by the rest of the world.

The Women's Mosque of America (WMOA) recently opened the doors of its second location in Los Angeles, California. This new mosque, the first to be founded by a woman in the United States, is opening its doors not just to women, but to men as well.The Women's Mosque of America is a non-profit organization founded by community activist Sana Muttalib, who is a first-generation Muslim. Muttalib started the organization in 2015 to “help cultivate a space that provides a holistic view of American Muslim life by prioritizing the voices, leadership and spiritual growth of women and girls.”The WMOA Los Angeles houses an Islamic learning center, a café, and a multi-faith space that is open to anyone who wants to come in. The mosque offers traditional prayers, classes, lectures, workshops and much more. Furthermore, the Women's Mosque of America offers a platform for women to give speeches and lead Friday sermons, which is something rarely seen in mosques in the United States."The mission of WMOA is to create a peaceful, inclusive space of spiritual and intellectual growth," Muttalib said. "I feel a deep sense of gratitude knowing that we can honor that mission while including men in our congregations and programming."The Women's Mosque of America has become a beacon of hope for female empowerment within the Muslim community. Muttalib is looking forward to continue her work to raise awareness and give back to her community.

Italian researchers have made a breakthrough in the field of robotics, developing a robotic hand that is lighter and cheaper than the models currently available on the market. The team at the Italian Institute of Technology (IIT) designed the new robotic hand to resemble a human hand, providing users with a realistic motion capability and aesthetic. The creators of the device, Dr. Darwin Caldwell and Dr. Matteo Laffranchi, managed to make the robotic hand smaller, lighter and cheaper compared to similar models.The robotic hand is composed of four motors to move each finger, nine actuators for each joint, two for the wrist, and a force sensor in the thumb. While it costs around €2,000 to €2,500, its counterparts generally cost more than €3,000. Dr. Caldwell and Dr. Laffranchi hope that the new robotic hand will be useful in a variety of scenarios, such as prosthetics, manufacturing and rescue missions.“We designed the hand to reduce size, weight, complexity, and cost, but still allowing for life-like motions and dexterous grasping,” said Dr. Caldwell. The researchers are currently exploring the potential of using the robotic hand in medical applications, such as tele-rehabilitation, and are confident that their device will have a wide range of uses.

Mozambique is getting ready for its presidential elections, which will take place on October 15th. The political parties of the Republic of Mozambique are expected to field candidates for the election and the Electoral Commission has started registering voters for the poll.The political tensions have been increasing in the southern African nation as the election approaches. A dispute between the ruling Mozambique Liberation Front (FRELIMO) and the main opposition party RENAMO has resulted in several clashes in the past few months. The government and the opposition have accused each other of stirring up violence.The international community has expressed concern about the situation. The United Nations has called for a peaceful election and urged all parties to participate in the process. They have also urged the government to ensure a free and fair vote.The Mozambican government has promised that the elections will be fair and peaceful. The government has deployed additional police officers to protect the polling stations and security forces have been instructed to use only necessary force. The government is also closely monitoring social media to detect any attempts to spread misinformation.The country is hopeful that the elections will bring about much-needed stability and a brighter future for the people of Mozambique.

The Catholic Diocese of California is facing a major lawsuit filed by 20 plaintiffs alleging sexual abuse within its ranks. The plaintiffs include six current and former nuns, one priest, and several lay people associated with the Church.The lawsuit, filed in San Diego County Superior Court, seeks damages for years of alleged abuse. It accuses some of the state's top Catholic bishops, including the Bishop of Los Angeles, of failing to investigate claims of abuse and neglect. The lawsuit also accuses the bishops of failing to remove abusers from positions of power, allowing them to remain in ministry and continue abusing.The plaintiffs allege that the Church's pattern of cover-ups has allowed the abuse to continue unchecked for years, noting that some of the accused bishops have been in their positions for decades. They accuse the Church of negligence, breach of fiduciary duty, and recklessness.The Diocese has released a statement condemning the allegations and promising to investigate the claims. It has not yet commented on the lawsuit. The plaintiffs are seeking unspecified compensatory and punitive damages, which they plan to use to fund mental health services for survivors of abuse.The lawsuit is a major development in the ongoing effort to hold the Catholic Church accountable for its part in perpetuating a culture of silence around sexual abuse. The plaintiffs are determined to make their voices heard and bring justice to victims of abuse.

The results of Ukraine's presidential election have been widely disputed, with the two leading candidates each declaring victory. Incumbent President Petro Poroshenko has claimed that exit polls are evidence that he has won, while his opponent Volodymyr Zelensky has also declared himself the winner.The two men have been locked in a tense battle for the presidency since the first round of voting in March. The latest survey, conducted by the Kiev International Institute of Sociology, gave Poroshenko a 5% lead over Zelensky, with the incumbent on 53.7%, and Zelensky on 48.7%.However, the Ukrainian Central Election Commission has yet to declare a clear winner. This could mean that the final results may take a few days or weeks to confirm. There are also some concerns that the election was marred by irregularities, which could delay the final announcement even further.With both candidates claiming victory and a high level of uncertainty, tensions remain high in Ukraine. The country is anxiously awaiting a decision from the Election Commission that can settle the dispute and bring some level of stability to the region.

The death toll from the tsunami that hit parts of the United States has risen to 36, the National Weather Service said on Sunday.The devastating tsunami, generated by an 8.0 magnitude earthquake off the coast of Alaska, swept across Southcentral Alaska and parts of California late last week. Waves of up to 30 feet (9.1 meters) high were reported in some areas, and the damage from the tsunami was still being assessed as of Sunday.The National Weather Service warned of potentially severe impacts as strong waves and currents persisted in some places. Officials urged residents in affected areas to take caution and stay out of the water.At least 36 people have been confirmed dead, according to the National Weather Service, with thousands more in need of medical attention.

Native American women continue to face high rates of crime despite recent reforms. This is according to a report released by the US Department of Justice on Tuesday.The report found that Native American women are 2.5 times more likely to experience sexual violence than other ethnic groups, and more than twice as likely to experience physical violence. It also revealed that more than four in five Native American women have experienced some form of violence in their lifetime.The Justice Department has implemented a range of reforms in recent years, including the launch of its Violence Against Women Reauthorization Act (VAWA). This includes initiatives that provide resources and support for victims, as well as preventative strategies such as tribal courts and initiatives to reduce poverty and build safer communities.The report also looked at Native American women's experiences of domestic and sexual violence in the context of their legal rights, revealing how often tribal justice systems fail to provide justice.Despite the introduction of these reforms, the report found that Native American women continue to face disproportionate levels of violence. This is due to a range of factors including poverty, substance abuse, and discrimination.Native American women continue to experience violence at higher rates than other ethnic groups and this must be addressed if we are to truly combat these issues. The Justice Department’s reform efforts are a step in the right direction, but more must be done to ensure the safety and justice of Native American women.

A leading human rights group has warned that Syria is now the only nation in the world that continues to use cluster munitions.In a recent statement, the New York-based Human Rights Watch (HRW) highlighted the shocking reality that no other countries are currently known to be utilizing the indiscriminate and often deadly weapons. Cluster munitions are banned internationally and can cause immense suffering, according to the group.Cluster munitions are released from the air or ground and contain many small “bomblets” which can maim and kill indiscriminately in a wide area. According to HRW, Syria has used cluster munitions extensively since 2012, primarily in opposition-controlled areas, resulting in civilian casualties.Though Syria has not yet signed the 2008 Convention on Cluster Munitions, HRW is calling on the government of Bashar al-Assad to immediately halt its use of the weapon and join the treaty, which prohibits the use, production, stockpiling, and transfer of cluster munitions.Rolando Gomez, a spokesman for HRW, said: “Syria’s use of cluster munitions casts a deadly shadow over a generation of Syrian children. The death and injuries inflicted by these horrific weapons will persist long after the last bombs are dropped.”He added that for the ban on cluster munitions to be effective, all countries must reject these weapons and also pressure those that continue to use them. “Any state that uses cluster munitions should face real consequences,” Gomez said.

The International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTY) has proposed the transfer of three war crimes cases to either Croatia or Serbia.The Hague prosecutors have recommended that the cases be sent to the appropriate domestic court. The three cases in question are all related to crimes against humanity, including deportation, extermination and rape.This suggestion follows an earlier appeal by Chief Prosecutor Serge Brammertz to the court to transfer the cases in order to conclude the ICTY’s business.In a statement on the matter, Brammertz said: "The time has come for the Tribunal to begin passing on the legacy of accountability it has forged over the years. This requires us to maintain an efficient and effective system, which necessitates the transfer of cases to domestic courts."The Hague court has been in operation since 1993 and has handled a number of trials related to war crimes committed in the former Yugoslavia.

The death toll from flash floods in Iran has risen to 44, the Iranian Red Crescent Society said on Saturday.The Red Crescent Society said that the death toll had risen significantly due to an increase in the number of people affected by the floods and subsequent mudslides. Hundreds of volunteers and rescuers have been working around the clock in efforts to save those affected, as the floods have spread to 13 provinces in the country.

Ministers from African countries are gathering in Addis Ababa to examine strategies for unleashing the continent's economic potential.The two-day conference will bring together ministers from member countries of the African Union to discuss how to best create economic opportunities. Discussions will focus on job creation, infrastructure development, regional integration, financing and technological advances in industry.Leading the talks are African Union Commission Chairperson Moussa Faki Mahamat and Commissioner for Economy, Science, Technology and Innovation Alfredo Teixeira, who stressed that the conference was an important step towards tackling the continent's greatest challenge."This is an opportunity for us to look to the future," said Mahamat. "We must unlock the African economy's potential for growth and development, and take advantage of the opportunities that will emerge."Teixeira agreed, saying, "We must mobilize Africa's resources to create opportunities that will enable our youth to access jobs and education. We will also be discussing strategies to increase regional integration and capitalize on Africa's digital revolution."The conference is part of the African Union's "Program for Infrastructure Development in Africa" initiative. With such an ambitious agenda, the meeting promises to be a defining moment in Africa's development and an opportunity to create a new future for the continent.

British Security Services are facing increasing questions over their surveillance priorities. The issue has come to a head recently, with news of the Security Service being accused of using their extensive powers to monitor a wide range of political activists and prominent campaigners.The accusations come in the wake of media reports detailing the Security Service's growing surveillance capabilities. While it is not known if any of the targets of the monitoring were involved in any illegal activity, the revelation that they were targeted for surveillance has raised concerns over the use of the Security Services' resources.Critics have expressed concerns that the Security Services are placing too much emphasis on the activities of political activists and campaigners, and not enough focus on more pressing issues, such as terrorist activity or the fight against serious and organised crime.The Security Service is yet to comment on the accusations. However, sources close to the organisation have suggested that they are taking the issue of their surveillance priorities seriously, and have opened an internal review of their operations to ensure that their resources are being used effectively.The government has also been questioned over its role in the issue, with calls for greater oversight of the Security Service and more transparency over their operations. The government is yet to respond to these calls.For now, it is yet to be seen how the issue of the Security Services' surveillance priorities will be addressed. It is clear, however, that many people are becoming increasingly concerned over the use of these powerful resources, and the lack of transparency around their operations.

The World Health Organization (WHO) and the United Nations (UN) have hailed the potential of an innovative gel which is being developed to reduce the risk of HIV and AIDS infection in women.Developed by the International Partnership for Microbicides (IPM), the gel contains antiretroviral drugs which are proven to be highly effective in blocking HIV transmission. It has been designed to be applied inside the vagina during sex, providing a discreet and user-friendly way for women to protect themselves from infection.The gel is currently in a third phase of clinical trials and has already been shown to reduce risk of infection by more than 50%. According to Dr. Zeda Rosenberg, CEO of IPM, the results of these trials could be "game-changing" for millions of women across the globe who are particularly vulnerable to HIV infection.The WHO and the UN have both applauded the potential of the product. “This groundbreaking gel could be a very real way to reduce the risk of HIV transmission in women”, said UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon. The trials are expected to be completed in 2014, with the gel being available for use in 2015 if the results of the trial are positive.

In times of tragedy, social media can be both a unifier and a divider. In the wake of recent disasters, such as the hurricanes that ravaged the United States and the earthquake that shook Mexico, social media platforms like Twitter, Instagram and Facebook have become essential tools in communicating news and raising funds.Through campaigns like #PrayforMexico and #HoustonStrong, social media has acted as a vehicle to spread awareness and build a sense of solidarity. Fundraisers set up on GoFundMe and other fundraising sites have helped to collect millions of dollars for victims, while many have used social media to offer shelters for those in need.But while social media can be used for good, it can also be used to sow discord. Many have used the sites to spread lies, rumors, and unfounded allegations. Furthermore, the comments that people make on social media have been known to have a polarizing effect.For many, however, social media is still seen as a source of comfort during times of tragedy. Through it, victims are not only connected with those who can help, but also with the support they need to cope with difficult times. Social media can act as a collective voice in times of despair, letting people know that even though they may be physically far apart, they are not alone.

Former European Union Trade Commissioner Pascal Lamy has been selected to lead the World Trade Organization (WTO).The appointment was announced today by WTO Director-General Roberto Azevedo and marks the first time the top position in the world's leading trade organization has been filled by someone from outside of the body since its inception in 1995.Lamy, who held the position of EU trade chief from 2004-2014, was chosen from an international pool of candidates and has been praised for his unwavering commitment to global economic stability and development."Pascal Lamy has an unparalleled understanding of the complex issues surrounding the World Trade Organization, and his unwavering commitment to the cause of global trade liberalization will make him an effective leader for the organization," said Azevedo.The 72-year-old Frenchman has held various high-level positions, such as European Commission Secretary-General, and has received numerous honors from the European Union.Lamy's term as WTO Director-General will begin on September 1, and is expected to last for four years. He takes over the role from current Director-General Roberto Azevedo, whose tenure will end in August.

Philippine troops have killed three communist rebels in the southern part of the country, the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP) said on Wednesday. According to the AFP, the incident happened in the early morning of Tuesday in an area known as Lake Sebu in South Cotabato. In a statement, the AFP said the three rebels were killed after they engaged troops in a "firefight."The statement did not identify the slain rebels, who are said to be part of the outlawed Communist Party of the Philippines (CPP). The AFP said they were able to recover firearms and other materials from the rebels after the incident.

Senator John McCain is refusing to give up the fight, even as he battles a health condition described by his office as "a serious type of cancer".The 80-year-old senator from Arizona, who has served since 1987, has been diagnosed with glioblastoma, a type of brain tumor. The news broke last week and has created waves of support from senators of both parties.Sen. McCain released a statement, saying, "I greatly appreciate the outpouring of support - unfortunately for my sparring partners in Congress, I'll be back soon, so stand-by!"Despite the diagnosis, McCain, a former prisoner of war in Vietnam and two-time presidential candidate, is still pushing for reform and showing up to fulfill his duties. On Wednesday, he was present for a Senate Armed Services Committee hearing to hear witnesses testify on national security challenges in Afghanistan.This is not the first health issue the senator has faced.
